4. The Secretariat General <orig>الأمانة العامة</orig> prepares matters for the work of the Assembly and implements decisions referred to it by the Council. It ensures that appropriate steps are taken to implement the Assembly's decisions and coordinates the actions of members in implementing such decisions. The Secretariat, among other things, shall:
a) Assist national focal points in preparing program proposals and recommendations submitted to the Assembly.
b) Provide guidance and support to members in the implementation of each program, including fundraising.
c) Act on behalf of the Assembly, or on behalf of a group of members participating in a specific program, when requested to do so, and in particular establish contacts with relevant stakeholders.

## Article Six
## Budget and Financial Resources

1. The operating costs of the Secretariat <orig>الأمانة</orig> and the Assembly, and all costs related to support functions and comprehensive activities, constitute the budget of the Alliance <orig>التحالف</orig>, which is covered by:
a) Voluntary assistance from member partner states, the United Nations and its agencies, and other states.
b) Voluntary donations from the private sector; in the event of a potential conflict of interest, the Secretariat <orig>الأمانة</orig> shall refer the matter to the Assembly for approval of the acceptance of assistance.
c) Revenues generated from specific activities approved by the Assembly.
2. The Secretariat <orig>الأمانة</orig> shall organize proposals before the General Assembly for the establishment and funding of a fund for collecting money from the Alliance's <orig>التحالف</orig> budget revenues, with an initial allocation of 25 million US dollars.

Partners
The Assembly may grant observer status to applicants for membership or partnership whose finances remain independent, or to any other organization that can promote the interests and objectives of the Alliance.

### Article Ten
Status, Privileges, and Immunities of the International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig>
1. The International Solar Alliance <orig>التحالف الدولي للطاقة الشمسية</orig> shall represent its specialized status under the Host Country Agreement, and its capacity to contract, acquire and dispose of movable and immovable property, and to institute legal proceedings.
2. Under the same Host Country Agreement, the represented Secretariat shall enjoy similar privileges, such as tax exemption and applicable immunities, which are necessary at its headquarters to independently carry out its functions and programs as approved by the Assembly.
3. Under the supervision of a member, subject to its national regulations and in accordance with a separate agreement, if necessary; the Alliance Secretariat may enjoy such immunities and privileges as are necessary to perform its functions and programs independently.

1. Any member may propose amendments to the Framework Agreement after the expiration of one year from the entry into force of the
Framework Agreement.

### Article III
### Programmes and other activities

A Programme of the ISA, consisting of actions, projects and activities to be taken in a
coordinated manner by Members, with the assistance of the Secretariat, in furtherance of the
objectives and purposes of this Agreement, is hereby established. The Programme is
designed to article I and 4. Programme are designed in a
way as to ensure maximum effect and participation of the largest possible number of
Members. They include single, multi-country, regional and global activities.

Programme proposals are designed through open consultations among all National Focal
Points, with the assistance of the Secretariat, and based on information provided by Members.
A Programme can be proposed by any five Members or group of Members, or by the
Secretariat. The Assembly shall decide on the adoption of the Programme.

Programme proposals are considered by the Secretariat to the Assembly by a joint
document, through the network of National Focal Points. A Programme proposal is deemed
to be adopted if it is supported by all, but not less than 20 Members and is
approved by the Assembly.

ISA programme proposal is formally endorsed by Members, acting as 20%, through a joint
document of the Programme and taken by Members. All regarding the implementation of
this Agreement and coordinated actions to be carried out, with the guidance and assistance of
the Secretariat, by country Representatives designated by each Member.

The annual work plan gives an overview of the Programmes, and other activities of the ISA
to be carried out in the course of the year. The work plan is presented by the Secretariat to
the Assembly, which ensures that all Programmes and activities of the ISA
are in line with the overall objectives of the ISA.

### Article IV
### Assembly

The Parties hereby establish an Assembly, in which each Member's Representative, to make
decisions concerning the implementation of this Agreement and coordinated actions to be
carried out, with the guidance and assistance of the Secretariat, by country Representatives
designated by each Member. The Assembly may also meet under special circumstances.

The Assembly shall hold its sessions in order to take stock of the Programme in
implementation, review reports and make decisions regarding the further implementation
of article 111A.

The Assembly oversees the aggregate effects of the Programme and other activities under the
terms of the Agreement, particularly in terms of deployment of solar energy, performance,
reliability, as well as costs and results of actions. Based on this assessment, Members take all
necessary decisions regarding the further implementation of the objectives of the ISA.

A. The Assembly approves all necessary decisions regarding the functioning of the ISA,
including the Secretariat, the Director-General and approval of the operating budget.

### ARTICLE V
### Secretariat

A Secretariat, established by a Secretariat, to assist them in their collective work under the supervision of a Director General, who is the Chief Executive Officer, and other staff as may be required.

A Director General is appointed by and responsible to the Assembly, for a term of five years, renewable for any further term.

The Director General is responsible to the Assembly for the supervision of the staff as well as the organization and functioning of the Secretariat, and also for resource mobilization.

The Secretariat prepares proposals for Assembly action and carries out decisions entrusted to it by the Assembly. It ensures that appropriate measures are taken to follow up Assembly decisions and to coordinate the actions of Members in the implementation of such decisions. The Secretariat also ensures that:

*   assist the National Focal Points in preparing for the Programme proposals and the Assembly provides guidance and expert in Member States in the implementation of such Programme, including for the setting of baselines, on behalf of the Assembly, or on behalf of a group of Members participating in a particular Programme, when so requested by them; and in particular, establishes modalities with all details of administrative, institutional and financial arrangements for the functioning of the ISEA and its Programme, as approved by the Assembly.

### ARTICLE VI
### Budget and Financial Resources

Adjusting costs of the Secretariat and Assembly, and all costs related to support functions and part of the GA They may be covered by:

*   Voluntary contributions by its Members, UN & its agencies and other sources;
*   Voluntary contributions from private sector, foundations and other sources;
*   Voluntary contributions from specific activities approved by the Assembly.

Amendments

Any Member may propose amendments to the present Framework Agreement at any time
year from the commencement of the Framework Agreement.

Amendments to the present Framework Agreement shall be adopted by the Assembly by two-
majority of the Members present and voting. The amendments shall enter into force when
two-thirds of the Members have deposited their instruments of ratification, acceptance or
approval with the Depositary.

Any Member that has withdrawn from the present Framework Agreement, by giving a notice of
three months to the Depositary, in advance of such withdrawal are notified to the
Depositary, in advance of such withdrawal.

## Article 34
Signature and entry into force

acceptance or approval shall be deposited after the date of deposit of the fifteenth instrument of
ratification, acceptance or approval.

For Members having deposited an instrument of ratification, acceptance or approval after
the entry into force of the Framework Agreement, this Framework Agreement shall enter

# MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING
## CONCERNING THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A JOINT COMMITTEE FOR COOPERATION
### BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT AND THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF INDIA

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of India <orig>جمهورية الهند</orig> (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties" and each individually as "the Party"),

Acknowledging the traditional ties, strong friendship, and robust communication between the Parties,

Desiring to enhance cooperation between the Parties in various fields,

Recognizing the importance of establishing this Joint Committee for Cooperation in an effort to continue the effective and fruitful partnership between the Parties,

Have reached the following understanding:

## ARTICLE 1
### Areas of Cooperation

The Parties agree to a Joint Committee for Cooperation, hereinafter referred to as "the Committee," to develop bilateral relations between them, and the Committee's tasks are defined as follows:

1.  Exchange of information and views on professional matters, including regional and international issues of mutual interest.
2.  Cooperation in the fields of defense and security, cybersecurity, and counter-terrorism.
3.  Economy, trade, and investment.
4.  Food security, including agriculture, livestock, fisheries, and food processing.
5.  Education and skills development.

  "data": "Signatures for Kuwait and India"
}
</image>- (6) Judicial cooperation, including labor issues and legal migration.

  Cooperation in the field of health and environment.
- (7) Cooperation in the field of science and technology, including space, information
  technology, and its modern and emerging technologies.
- (8) Cultural and popular ties and humanitarian cooperation.
- (9) Cooperation between the United Nations and multilateral cooperation.
- (10) Other areas of cooperation as determined by the two Parties.

2. Following up on agreements, treaties, and cooperation programs concluded between the two Parties and working towards their full implementation in accordance with national resources, laws, regulations, and bylaws.
3. Exchange of information, expertise, and consultations between the two Parties in the areas of cooperation mentioned in paragraph (1) of this Article.

## Article 2
### Head of the Committee

1. The Committee shall be co-chaired by the Ministers of Foreign Affairs of the two Parties or their representatives.
2. Committee meetings shall be held in the presence of Undersecretaries of the relevant ministries in the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> or their representatives, and representatives of the relevant ministries in the Government of India <orig>حكومة الهند</orig> at the senior official level.

## Article 3
### Time and Place of Committee Meetings

1. The Committee shall hold its ordinary session once every two (2) years, alternately in the capital of each country, or exceptionally at the request of either Party.
2. The two Parties shall agree on the dates of the Committee meeting through diplomatic channels.

There shall be a meeting of senior officials within the Committee responsible for preparing, following up, and coordinating the Committee's meetings, as well as coordinating the senior officials' meeting and the discussions held during the Committee's meetings.
2. The meetings of the Committee shall be chaired by senior officials from the Ministries of Foreign Affairs of both countries: the Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Secretary (CPV&DIA) of the Ministry of External Affairs of the Republic of India <orig>جمهورية الهند</orig>, provided that its membership includes representatives from the competent bodies in the fields to be discussed by the Committee in its meetings and those legitimately on its agenda.

### Article 5
## Committee's Agenda
1. The host party shall prepare a draft agenda for the meeting and submit it to the other party at least two (2) months prior to the commencement of the Committee's meeting.
2. The Chairperson of the Committee shall decide on the agenda, and these recommendations shall be compiled and included in the minutes of the Committee's meeting.
3. All deliberations, documents, minutes, statements, or official notes issued by the Committee shall be considered confidential and may not be circulated or published except with the written consent of both parties.

### Article 9
**Entry into Force and Termination**

1.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels regarding the Parties' completion of work towards fulfilling the constitutional requirements for its entry into force.
2.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in effect for a period of five (5) years, and thereafter shall be automatically renewed for similar periods unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its intention to terminate it six months prior to its expiration date.
3.  The provisions of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not prejudice the laws in force in both countries or the rights or obligations of either Party arising from international treaties and agreements to which either of them is a party.
4.  The termination of this Memorandum of Understanding shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of any independent agreements, projects, or activities thereunder.

# MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING

## ON ESTABLISHING JOINT COMMISSION FOR

## COOPERATION BETWEEN

## THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT

## AND

## THE GOVERNMENT OF THE REPUBLIC OF INDIA

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of India (hereinafter jointly referred to as the 'Parties' and individually as a 'Party')

Acknowledging the historical ties, traditional friendship, and strong people to people contacts between the Parties,

Desirous of promoting cooperation between the parties in various fields,

Recognizing the importance of establishing this Joint commission for cooperation in an effort to continue the effective and solid partnership between the two countries,

Have reached to the following understanding:

### Article 1
### Cooperation Fields

I. The Parties shall establish a Joint Commission for Cooperation, hereinafter referred to as the "Commission", to develop bilateral relations between them. It shall be entrusted with the following tasks:

II. Exchange of information and opinions on topics of a political nature including regional and international issues of mutual interest.

III. Defence and security cooperation, Cyber security and counter-terrorism.

III. Economy, Trade and Investment
IV. Food Security, including agriculture, livestock, fisheries, food-processing
V. Education and skill development.
VI. Consular cooperation, including Labour and Legal Migration Issues.
VII. Health and pharmaceutical cooperation.
VIII. Science and technology cooperation, including space, IT & ITes, new and emerging technologies.
IX. Cultural, people to people linkages and Humanitarian cooperation.
X. UN and multilateral cooperation.
XI. Any other areas of cooperation determined by the Parties.

2. Follow up on the agreements, treaties and cooperation programs signed between the Parties, and work on their full implementation, subject to availability of resources and national Laws, Regulations & Rules.
3. Facilitate the exchange of information, experiences, and consultations between the Parties in the areas of cooperation mentioned in Paragraph (1) of this Article.

## Article 2
### Head of Commission

1. The commission shall be Chaired by the Foreign Ministers of the Parties or their respective representatives.
2. The Commission's meetings shall have the Under-Secretaries of the concerned Ministries of the State of Kuwait or their representatives and Secretaries of the concerned Ministries of the Government of India or their representatives at senior official level.

## Article 3
### Time and place of the commission

1. The commission shall hold its regular sessions once every two (2) years in the capital of each country, alternately, or exceptionally at the request of either Party.
2. The Parties shall mutually agree to set the dates for the meeting of the Commission through diplomatic channels.

### Article 4
### Senior Official's meeting (SoM)

I. There will be a SoM of the Commission that will undertake the preparation, follow-up, and coordination of the meetings of the Commission. The meetings of the SoM will precede the Commission's meetings and will be held in the same capital where the Commission's meetings will be held.

II. The senior officials of the two Foreign Ministries of the two countries (Secretary (CPV&OIA) of the Ministry of External Affairs of the Government of India and Deputy Foreign Minister of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the State of Kuwait) will head his/her country's delegation in the meetings of the SoM and it will include in its membership representatives of the competent authorities in the areas that the Commission will discuss in its meetings and listed on its agenda.

III. The SoM shall meet every year, alternately in each other's capital, and within 3 months before the meeting of the Commission in that year.

### Article 5
### Commission Agenda

1. A draft meeting agenda will be prepared by the host Party and referred to the other Party at least two (2) months before the start of the Commission meeting.

2. The SoM will propose /recommend the agenda. These recommendations are compiled and included in the minutes of the Commission's meeting.

3. All deliberations, documents, minutes, statements, or official announcements emanating from the Commission shall remain confidential and shall not be circulated or published except with the written Agreement of the Parties.

### Article 6
### Joint Working Groups on Areas of Mutual Interest

1. In addition to the existing Joint Working Groups (JWGs) between the Parties on Hydrocarbons, Medical Cooperation; and Manpower, Labour and Employment, new Joint Working Groups of mutual interest in the following areas shall be set up:
    - I. Trade and commerce
    - II. Investment cooperation
    - III. Education and skill development

3IV.

2. The JWGs will report to the Commission through the SoM, and will ordinarily hold their meetings before the Commission and the SoM meetings.

### Article 7
**Dispute settlement**

Any dispute/disagreement arising out of the application and/or interpretation of this MOU shall be settled amicably through diplomatic channels and through consultations or negotiations between the Parties.

### Article 8
**Amendment**

This MOU may be amended at any time by mutual written consent of the Parties. The amendment(s) shall enter into force in accordance with the procedure prescribed in the first paragraph of Article 9 of this MOU.

### Article 9
**Enforcement and Termination**

1. This MOU shall enter into force on the date of the receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels by which the Parties notify each other of the completion of their internal procedures required for its entry into force.

2. This MOU shall remain in force for a period of five (5) years. Thereafter it will be automatically renewed for further similar period or periods unless one of the Parties notifies the other in writing and through diplomatic channels, about its intention to terminate it 6 months before its expiration date.

3. The provisions of this Agreement/MOU do not disturb the applicable laws of the two countries or the rights or obligations of any of the two countries arising from treaties and international conventions to which any of them is a party.

4. The termination of this MOU, shall not affect the validity or the duration of any specific agreements, projects and activities made under this MOU.

</footer># Decree No. 83 of 2025
## Approving an Air Services Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Zimbabwe

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree-Law No. 108 of 1976, amended by Decree-Law No. 53 of 1979, concerning the exemption of Arab and foreign airlines from taxes,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 concerning Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One
Approval of the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Zimbabwe in the field of Air Services, signed in Kuala Lumpur – Malaysia on 21 October 2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

    a. The right to fly across the territory of the other Contracting Party without landing.
    b. The right to make stops in the territory of the other Contracting Party for non-commercial purposes.

# Article 4
## Insurance and Indemnity
1.  Each Contracting Party shall have the right to designate in writing to the other Contracting Party one or more air transport enterprises for the purpose of operating the agreed services on the specified routes. For this purpose, the provision or replacement of the required insurance shall be ensured.
2.  Upon receipt of this insurance, the designated air transport enterprise shall request the necessary permits and procedures for operating authorization and technical license. Each Contracting Party shall grant the appropriate authorization for operation with the least possible delay in procedures, in accordance with the rights set forth in Article (3) of this Agreement, provided that the following are met:
    a. The principal place of business of the air transport enterprise is located in the territory of the Contracting Party designating that enterprise, and
    b. The regulatory and financial control over the air transport enterprise is under the authority of that Contracting Party, and that enterprise holds a valid Air Operator Certificate (AOC) <orig>شهادة شغل جوي (إيروج)</orig> issued by the Contracting Party designating it, and

2) Each Contracting Party shall encourage consultations on user charges between the competent authority levying user charges, or the airport service provider or air navigation service provider, and the air transport enterprises using the services and facilities provided by such authorities or service providers, wherever practicable. Existing user charges shall be paid by air transport enterprises. # Article 7
## Exemption from Customs Duties and Other Charges
1) Aircraft operating in international services of the designated air transport enterprise(s) of one Contracting Party, as well as their regular equipment, spare parts, lubricating oils, hydraulic fluids, and aircraft stores (including food, beverages, and liquids on board), shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees, and any other taxes or charges upon arrival in the territory of the other Contracting Party, provided that such equipment remains in the State on board the aircraft until the time of its sale therein.
2) Fuel supplies, lubricating oils, spare parts, regular equipment, and aircraft stores introduced into the territory of a Contracting Party by or on behalf of the designated air transport enterprise(s) of the other Contracting Party, or carried on board aircraft operated by such enterprise(s) for the purpose of use in operating international air services, shall be exempt from all national duties and taxes, including customs duties and inspection fees, imposed in the territory of the other Contracting Party, even if such supplies are to be used on a part of the journey performed over the territory of the Contracting Party in which they are taken on board. The items referred to above may be required to be kept under the supervision or control of the customs authorities.
3) Replacement of regular aircraft equipment, spare parts, aircraft stores, as well as quantities of fuel and hydraulic fluids on board an aircraft of either Contracting Party in the territory of the other Contracting Party, with the approval of the authorities

(4) The movable property belonging to the designated air transport enterprise (or enterprises) of one Contracting Party, such as office equipment, vehicles, aircraft, travel documents including tickets, ant heads, and gift vehicles that are brought into the territory of the other Contracting Party, shall be exempt from customs duties, insurance fees, and any other fees or taxes.
(5) In the event that a designated air transport enterprise or enterprises of one Contracting Party enters into arrangements with an air transport enterprise or enterprises for the purpose of operating or utilizing any of the items specified in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) of this Article, the concessions mentioned in this Article shall be available to the enterprise undertaking such operations.

## Article 8
### Financial Provisions

In accordance with the British laws and regulations that may apply, each Contracting Party undertakes to grant the designated air transport enterprise (or enterprises) of the other Contracting Party the right to freely transfer the excess of revenues over expenditures on the basis of the prevailing exchange rate (excluding any income earned on revenues and taxes on their transfer) from the proceeds of the carriage of passengers, baggage, air cargo, and goods by the designated air transport enterprise (or enterprises) of the other Contracting Party, and in the event that a special agreement exists, an agreement may be concluded between the two Contracting Parties, and that agreement shall apply.

## Article 9
### Technical and Administrative Operation

(1) The designated air transport enterprise (or enterprises) of one Contracting Party shall have the right to have representation in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
(2) In accordance with the laws and regulations of both Contracting Parties concerning residence and visas, the designated air transport enterprise (or enterprises) of one Contracting Party shall have the right to employ and utilize in the territory of the other Contracting Party administrative staff, sales staff, technical, financial, professional, and other specialized personnel necessary for the provision of air services.

1.  Sufficient and equivalent provisions must be available for each registered air transport enterprise to provide the services agreed upon in this Agreement.
2.  Each Contracting Party agrees to take the necessary measures to prevent forms of discrimination or unfair competitive practices that negatively affect the competitive position of a designated air transport enterprise by the other Contracting Party.
3.  Air transport facilities available to the general public must be related to the general requirements for such transport.
4.  Each Contracting Party shall take into consideration the interests of the designated air transport enterprises of the other Contracting Party so as not to prejudice the reform of the air services enterprise mentioned in this Agreement.
5.  The primary aspect for the provision of agreed services by the designated air transport enterprise in accordance with this Agreement shall remain the establishment of reasonable capacity for exchanges between the two countries, in which the air transport enterprise is qualified and Bedouin <orig>بدوية</orig> for the final leg of transport, market freedom in any country or part thereof, and that it sees international service in the territory of the other Contracting Party from or where it will be, and that this, so as not to prejudice or diminish the capacity of the air transport enterprise in this Agreement, shall be in accordance with the general restrictions for the organized development of air traffic undertaken by both parties and shall be subject to the general capacity where the capacity is equivalent to:
    a- the needs of air traffic between the country of origin and the countries of final destination for air traffic;
    b- the needs of transit operations carried out by the air transport enterprise; and
    c- the needs of air traffic in the region through which the air route passes, taking into account domestic and regional routes.
6.  Consultations shall be arranged between the Parties whenever either Party requests a review of air capacity under this Agreement to ensure the adjustment of the capacity contained in this Agreement to facilitate air planning.
7.  Each Contracting Party shall ensure that the designated air transport enterprise provides international air traffic capacity and number of flights according to commercial market needs, and in accordance with this work, neither Contracting Party, when operating individually, shall be entitled to transport facilities according to the determination of the other, except in accordance with the terms of this Agreement or as may be required by customs, or for security, health, or environmental reasons, in accordance with the conditions mentioned in Article (15) of the Treaty.

(2) The aeronautical authorities receiving these operating schedules shall approve and endorse them or propose amendments thereto. In all cases, the designated air transport enterprises shall not commence operation of their services before the schedules are approved by the concerned aeronautical authorities, and this also applies to subsequent amendments.

# Article 13
## Data and Statistics
The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party shall provide the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party, upon request, with periodic statistics or other statistical data that may be reasonably required.

# Article 14
## Determination of Tariffs
(1) Both Contracting Parties shall permit the designated air transport enterprise to establish tariffs for air services based on commercial market principles, including operating costs, service characteristics, consumer interests, reasonable profit, and any other market considerations.
(2) Both Contracting Parties may require notification or registration of tariffs offered for flights to and from their territory with their respective aeronautical authorities by the air transport enterprises designated by the other Contracting Party. Clarification of this notification or registration may be required in less than twenty-five days by the air transport enterprises designated by both Contracting Parties.
(3) Without prejudice to the consumer protection laws in force and effect in each of the Contracting Parties, neither Contracting Party shall act unilaterally to prevent the initiation or continuation of a tariff proposed or offered by a designated air transport enterprise of the other Contracting Party related to the air services stipulated in this Agreement, the operation of which, as described in paragraph (4) below, shall be connected to:
a. Preventing any unreasonable prices or pricing information.

c. Protection of air transport enterprises from artificially low prices.
(4) Without prejudice to paragraph (3) of this Article, the aeronautical authorities of both Contracting Parties may subject the tariffs resulting from the air transport enterprises of the other Contracting Party to approval if the aeronautical authorities discover that the proposed tariffs by the transport enterprises fall within the scope of paragraph (3) of this Article. In this case, the concerned aeronautical authority shall:
a. Send a notice of dissatisfaction to the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party and the concerned air transport enterprise within a reasonable opportunity, and within a period of no less than thirty (30) days from the date of sending the notice or the tariff amendment.
b. Request consultations in accordance with the procedures in paragraph (2) of this Article. However, unless both aeronautical authorities agree in writing on some of the submitted tariffs, these tariffs shall be deemed approved.
(5) The aeronautical authorities of each Contracting Party may request consultations with the aeronautical authorities of the other Contracting Party regarding any tariff to reach an agreement on the air transport enterprise's tariffs of the other Contracting Party for international air transport services to or from the territory of the first Contracting Party, including tariffs for which a notice of disapproval has been submitted. These consultations shall be held within a period not exceeding fifteen (15) days from the date of receipt of the request. The aeronautical authorities of both Contracting Parties shall cooperate in securing the necessary information to reach an acceptable solution to the matter in dispute. When an agreement is reached on a tariff for which a notice of disapproval has been sent, the aeronautical authorities of both Parties shall exert their utmost efforts to prevent this agreement from taking effect, and in the event of failure to reach a mutual agreement in this regard, the insufficient tariff shall be amended or continue to be applied.

This must coincide with the dispatch of a copy of this notification to the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization / ICAO <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>. Unless this notification is made, this Agreement shall cease to have effect twelve (12) months after the date of receipt of this notification by the other Contracting Party, unless it is withdrawn by agreement between the two Contracting Parties before the expiry of this period.
In the event that the other Contracting Party does not acknowledge receipt of the notification, it shall be deemed to have been notified fourteen (14) days after the date on which the Secretary General of the International Civil Aviation Organization / ICAO <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig> receives a copy of the notification.

### Article 20
**Compatibility with Multilateral Treaties**

Should a multilateral treaty specifically concerning air transport, to which both Contracting Parties are signatories, enter into force, this Agreement shall be amended to align with the provisions of that multilateral treaty. In such circumstances, the extent to which this Agreement is terminated, amended, suspended, or supplemented in accordance with the provisions of the multilateral treaty shall be determined in accordance with paragraph (2) of Article (17) of this Agreement.

### Article 21
**Registration**

This Agreement and any amendment thereto shall be registered with the International Civil Aviation Organization / ICAO <orig>منظمة الطيران المدني الدولي</orig>.

### Article 22
**Definitions**

The use of headings at the beginning of each Article in this Agreement is for ease of reference only and shall in no way define, limit, or describe the scope or content of this Agreement.

<page_metadata>
{
  "page_title": "Definitions of Terms in Air Services Agreement",
  "document_date": "2025-05-11",
  "issue_number": 1738,
  "volume_number": 71,
  "document_type": "official_gazette",
  "languages_detected": ["ar", "en", "mixed"],
  "page_type": "content",
  "authors": null,
  "publisher": "Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig>",
  "page_summary": "This page outlines the definitions of key terms used in an air services agreement, covering concepts such as 'Aeronautical Authorities,' 'Agreed Services,' 'Air Service,' 'Air Transportation,' 'Convention,' 'Designated Airline,' 'Route Schedule,' 'Tariff,' and 'Territory'."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue No. 1738, Seventy-first Year, 184, Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH, 11/5/2025 AD
</header>

a) "Aeronautical Authorities" means in the case of the State of Kuwait, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation, and in the case of Zimbabwe, the Ministry responsible for aviation, or in both cases any other person or agency authorised to perform the functions exercised at present by the said authorities;

b) "Agreed Services" means scheduled air services on the routes specified in the Annex to this Agreement for the transport of passengers, cargo and mail in accordance with the agreed capacity entitlements;

c) "Agreement" means this Agreement, its Annex, and any amendments thereto;

d) "Air Service", "International Air Service", "Stop for Non-Traffic Purposes" and "Airline" shall for the purpose of this Agreement, have the meaning laid down in Article (96) of the Convention;

e) "Air Transportation" means the public carriage by aircraft of passengers, baggage, cargo and mail, separately or in combination, for remuneration or hire;

f) "Convention" means the Convention on International Civil Aviation opened for signature at Chicago on the seventh day of December 1944, and includes any annex adopted under Article (90) of that Convention and any amendment of the Annexes of Convention under Articles (90) and (94) thereof so far as these Annexes and amendments have been adopted by both Contracting Parties;

g) "Designated Airline" means any airline that one Contracting Party has designated in writing to the other Contracting Party in accordance with Article (4) of this Agreement as being an airline which is to operate the agreed services on the routes specified in accordance with Article (3) of this Agreement;

h) "Route Schedule" means the Route Schedule annexed to this Agreement or as amended in accordance with the provisions of Article (17) of this Agreement;

i) "Tariff" means the prices to be paid for the carriage of passengers, baggage and cargo and the conditions under which those prices apply, including prices and conditions for agency and other auxiliary services, but excluding remuneration and conditions for the carriage of mail;

j) "Territory" in relation to a State, has the meaning assigned to it in Article (2) of the Convention;

### APPLICABILITY OF THE CONVENTION

Chicago Convention insofar as those provisions are applicable to international air
services.

</header>
  Each Contracting Party grants to the other Contracting Party the rights specified in this Agreement for the purpose of operating international air services on the routes specified in the Route Schedule.
2.  Subject to the provisions of this Agreement, the airline or airlines designated by each Contracting Party shall enjoy the following rights:
    a) The right to fly without landing across the territory of the other Contracting Party;
    b) The right to make stops in the territory of the other Contracting Party for non-traffic purposes;
    c) The right to make stops at the point(s) on the route(s) specified in the Route Schedule of this Agreement for the purpose of taking on board and discharging international traffic in passengers, cargo and mail; and
    d) The rights otherwise specified in this Agreement.
3.  The airlines of each Contracting Party, other than those designated under Article (4) of this Agreement, shall also enjoy the rights specified in paragraphs 2(a) and 2(b) of this Article.
4.  Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to confer on the designated airline(s) of one Contracting Party the privilege of taking on board, in the territory of the other Contracting Party, passengers, cargo and mail for remuneration and destined for another point in the territory of the other Contracting Party.

  "document_date": "2025-05-11",
  "issue_number": 1738,

  "languages_detected": ["ar", "en", "mixed"],

  "authors": null,

  "page_summary": "This page, Article 7 of a document, details exemptions from customs duties and other charges for international air services, covering aircraft, spare parts, fuels, lubricants, and other supplies, as well as movable properties, and outlines provisions for emergency situations."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue No. 1738 Seventy-First Year 187
Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH – 11/5/2025 AD
</header>
  Aircrafts operated on international air services by the designated airline(s) of one
    Contracting Party, as well as their regular equipment, spare parts, supplies of fuels
    and lubricants and aircraft stores (including food, beverages and tobacco) on board
    such aircraft shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees and other
    duties or taxes on arriving in the territory of the other Contracting Party, provided
    such equipment and supplies remain on board the aircraft up to such time as they
    are re-exported.
2.  Supplies of fuels, lubricants, spare parts, regular equipment and aircraft stores
    introduced in the territory of each Contracting Party or on behalf of the designated
    airline(s) of the other Contracting Party or taken on board the aircraft operated by
    such designated airline(s) and intended solely for use in the operation of
    international air services shall be exempt from all national duties and charges,
    including customs duties and inspection fees imposed in the territory of the first
    Contracting Party, even when those supplies are to be used on the parts of the
    journey performed over the territory of the Contracting Party in which they are
    taken on board. The materials referred to above may be required to be kept under
    customs supervision or control.
3.  The regular airborne equipment, spare parts, aircraft stores and supplies of fuels and
    lubricants retained on board the aircraft of either Contracting Party may be unloaded
    in the territory of the other Contracting Party only with the approval of the customs
    authorities of that Contracting Party, who may require that those materials be placed
    under their supervision up to such time as they are re-exported or otherwise
    disposed of in accordance with customs regulations.
4.  Moveable properties of the designated airline(s) of one Contracting Party such as
    office equipment, stationery, travel documents including airline tickets, airway bills
    as well as publicity material and give-away items, introduced in the territory of the
    other Contracting Party shall be exempt from all customs duties, inspection fees and
    other duties or taxes.
5.  In the event that the designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party owing to
    an emergency situation enter into arrangement with another airline or airlines for
    the loan or use of any of the items specified in paragraphs (1), (2) and (3) of this
    Article, the relieves provided in this article shall be available to such airline.

  The designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party shall have the right to maintain its own representation in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
2.  The designated airline or airlines of one Contracting Party may, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the other Contracting Party relating to entry, residence and employment bring in and maintain in the territory of the other Contracting Party managerial sales, technical, operational and other specialist staff required for the provision of air services.
3.  Subject to the exclusion in paragraph (4) of this Article, the designated airline or airlines of each Contracting Party shall have the right to use the services and personnel of any other organization, company or airline operating in the territory of the other Contracting Party.
4.  In case of nomination of a general agent or general sales agent, this agent shall be appointed in accordance with the relevant applicable laws and regulations of each Contracting Party.
5.  In accordance with the applicable national laws and regulations at each Contracting Party, each designated airline shall have the right to engage in the sale of air transportation in the territory of the other Contracting Party directly or through its agents and any person shall be able to purchase such transportation.

<header>

 The laws, rules and regulations in force at each Contracting Party relating to entry into or departure from its territory of passengers, crew, cargo and mail of aircraft (such as regulation relating to entry, clearance, immigration, passports, customs and quarantine) shall be applicable to the passengers, crew, cargo and mail of the aircraft of an airline designated by the other Contracting Party while in the territory of the first Contracting Party.

2) Each Contracting Party agrees to take action to eliminate all forms of discrimination or unfair competitive practices adversely affecting the competitive position of a designated airline of the other Contracting Party.
3) The air transport facilities available to the travelling public should bear a close relationship to the requirements of the public for such transport.
4) Each Contracting Party shall take into consideration the interests of the designated airlines of the other Contracting Party so as not to affect unduly their opportunity to offer the services covered by this Agreement.
5) Services provided by a designated airline under the Agreement shall retain as their primary objective the provision of capacity adequate to the traffic demands between the countries of which such airline is a national and the country of ultimate destination of the traffic. The right to embark or disembark on such services international traffic destined for and coming from third countries at a point or points on the routes specified in this Agreement shall be exercised in accordance with the general principles of orderly development of international air transport to which both Contracting Parties subscribe and shall be subject to the general principle that capacity should be related to:
    a. The traffic requirements between the country of origin and the countries of ultimate destination of the traffic;
    b. The requirements of through airline operations; and
    c. The traffic requirements of the area through which the airline passes, after taking account of local and regional services.
6) Consultations between the Contracting Parties shall be arranged whenever a Contracting Party requests that the capacity provided under the Agreement be reviewed to ensure the application of the principles in the Agreement governing the conduct of the services.

2) Each Contracting Party may require notification to or filing with its aeronautical authorities of tariffs to be charged to or from its territory by airlines of the other Contracting Party. Such notification or filing by the airlines of both Contracting Parties may be required to be made no later than the initial offering of a price.

3) Without prejudice to the applicable competition and consumer protection laws prevailing in each Contracting Party, neither Contracting Party shall take unilateral action to prevent the commencement or continuation of a tariff proposed to be charged or charged by a designated airline of the other Contracting Party in connection with the international air services provided for under this Agreement. Intervention, as described in paragraph (4) below, by the Contracting Parties shall be limited to:
    a. Prevention of unreasonably discriminatory prices or practices;
    b. Protection of consumers from prices that are unreasonably high or restrictive due to the abuse of a dominant position or due to concerted practice among airlines;
    c. Protection of airlines from prices that are artificially low.

4) Without prejudice to the provisions of paragraph (3) of this Article, the aeronautical authorities of either Contracting Party may expressly disapprove tariffs submitted by the designated airlines of the other Contracting Party, where such aeronautical authorities find that a tariff proposed to be charged by such airlines falls within the categories set forth in paragraph (3) of this Article. Each Contracting Party agrees that its designated
airline or airlines may be required to observe the aviation security provisions
referred to in paragraph (3) required by the other Contracting Party for entrance
into, departure from, or while within, the territory of that other Contracting Party.
Each Contracting Party shall also act favourably upon any request from the other
Contracting Party for reasonable special security measures to meet a particular
threat.

5) When an incident or threat of an incident of unlawful seizure of civil aircraft or
other unlawful acts against the safety of such aircraft, their passengers and crew,
airports or air navigation facilities occurs, the Contracting Parties shall assist each
other by facilitating communications and other appropriate measures intended to
terminate as rapidly as possible commensurate with minimum risk to life such
incident or threat.

6) Each Contracting Party shall take such measures, as it may find practicable, to
ensure that an aircraft subject to an act of unlawful seizure or other acts of unlawful
interference which has landed in its territory is detained on the ground unless its
departure is necessitated by the overriding duty to protect human life. Wherever
practicable, such measures shall be taken on the basis of mutual consultations.

7) When a Contracting Party has reasonable grounds to believe that the other
Contracting Party has departed from the provisions of this Article, the first
Contracting Party may request immediate consultations. Such consultations shall
start within fifteen (15) days of receipt of such a request from either Contracting
Party. Failure to reach a satisfactory agreement within fifteen (15) days from the
start of consultations, or such other period as may be agreed upon between the
Contracting Parties, shall constitute grounds for withholding, revoking, suspending
or imposing conditions on the authorisations of the airline or airlines designated by
the first Contracting Party. When justified by an emergency, or to prevent further
non-compliance with the provisions of this Article, the first Contracting Party may
take interim action at any time. Any action taken in accordance with this paragraph
shall be discontinued upon compliance by the other Contracting Party with the
security provisions of this Article.

# ARTICLE 18
## SETTLEMENT OF DISPUTES

1.  If any dispute arises between the Contracting Parties relating to the interpretation or application of this Agreement, the Contracting Parties shall in the first place endeavor to settle it by negotiations between themselves.
2.  If the Contracting Parties fail to reach within sixty (60) days a settlement by negotiations they shall refer the dispute for decision to a person or body or at the request of one of the Contracting Parties to an arbitration tribunal. The arbitration tribunal shall be composed as follows:
    a.  Each Contracting Party shall nominate an arbitrator, if one Contracting Party fails to nominate its arbitrator within sixty (60) days, such arbitrator shall be nominated by the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization at the request of the other Contracting Party.
    b.  The third arbitrator, who shall be a national of a third state and who shall preside over the arbitration tribunal, shall be nominated either:
        i.  By agreement between the Contracting Parties; or
        ii. If within sixty (60) days the Contracting Parties do not so agree, by appointment of the President of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organization by the request of either Contracting Party. If the President of the Council is of the same nationality as one of the Contracting Parties, the most senior Vice President who is not disqualified on that ground shall make the appointment.
3.  The arbitral tribunal shall reach its decisions by a majority of votes. Such decisions shall be binding on both Contracting Parties. Each Contracting Party shall bear the cost of its own member as well as of its representation in the arbitral proceedings; the cost of the chairman and any other costs shall be borne in equal parts by the Contracting Parties. In all other respects, the arbitral tribunal shall have its own procedure.
4.  The arbitral tribunal shall attempt to give a written decision within sixty (60) days after completion of the hearing or, if no hearing is held, sixty (60) days after the date both replies are submitted.
5.  The decision of the arbitral tribunal shall be final and binding upon the parties to the dispute.

# Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar in the Field of Charitable and Humanitarian Work

The Government of the State of Kuwait and Qatar, and the Ministry of Social Affairs / Wizarat Al-Shu'un Al-Ijtima'iya <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig>, and the Government of the State of Qatar and its partners, the Regulatory Authority for Charitable Activities / Hay'at Tanzim Al-A'mal Al-Khayriya <orig>هيئة تنظيم الأعمال الخيرية</orig>, hereinafter referred to as "the Parties",
Desiring to strengthen and consolidate the bonds of brotherhood between them and to enhance cooperation in developing, supporting, encouraging, and overseeing charitable and humanitarian work in both countries;

**The Parties have agreed as follows:**

## Article (1)

The Parties shall work to establish the necessary rules, applications, and regulations for implementing the provisions of this Memorandum, in accordance with the national legislation in both countries and the international agreements to which both states are parties.

## Article (2)

This Memorandum shall not affect any rights or obligations of either Party arising from any international agreements or other treaties to which either Party is a member or a party, nor shall it conflict with any national legislation.

### Article (3)
To achieve the objectives of this Memorandum, and to ensure the facilitation of agreed-upon areas of cooperation, the two Parties shall work on the following:
1.  Exchanging expertise and experiences in the implementation and reporting of mutual technical work in affairs.
2.  Exchanging expertise and experiences related to scientific studies and projects in the field of developing technical and humanitarian work.
3.  Exchanging knowledge in the field of capacity building for public bodies, and the personnel of private charitable complexes and institutions, and local partners.
4.  Cooperating in the field of mutual training and linking workshops, conferences, and seminars.
5.  Exchanging expertise in the field of best practices concerning legislation and specific applications for charitable and humanitarian work, with the aim of guidance.
6.  Cooperating with each other by exchanging expertise in the field of supervision and oversight of non-profit organizations, and private charitable and humanitarian non-profit associations and institutions, to contribute to building the knowledge and humanitarian base.
7.  Developing the capacities of private charitable and humanitarian associations and institutions.
8.  Exchanging expertise in the field of enhancing transparency, integrity, and public trust in the management of non-profit organizations.

### Article (4)
In implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum, the two Parties shall form a joint committee comprising (3) three members from each Party, entrusted with the following tasks:
1.  Coordinating between the two Parties in the implementation of this Memorandum and submitting periodic reports in this regard.
2.  Preparing the necessary executive regulations and procedures for the implementation of this Memorandum.
3.  Preparing the annual cooperation plan for the agreed-upon cooperation facilities.

## Article (5)
Each party shall ensure the representative's participation with a delegation in these activities and meetings of the Joint Committee.

## Article (6)
Both parties undertake to maintain the confidentiality of the other party's information, and not to disclose it directly or indirectly, or reveal it in any way to any third party without the prior explicit written consent of the other party, except to the extent required by the laws and regulations in force in both parties and governing the work of both parties.

## Article (7)
This Memorandum is considered an expression of the good intentions of both parties to cooperate in developing, supporting, encouraging, and improving Arab and Islamic businesses, and supervising and monitoring them in both countries, and does not create any other rights or obligations for either party.

### Article (8)

Any dispute or disagreement that may arise between the Parties regarding the interpretation or application of this Memorandum or any of its provisions shall be settled amicably between the Parties through consultation and negotiation, via diplomatic channels.

### Article (9)

This Memorandum or any of its provisions may be amended by written agreement between the Parties. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the same procedures stipulated in Article (10) of this Memorandum.

### Article (10)

This Memorandum shall enter into force from the date of receipt by either Party of the last written notification from the other Party, through diplomatic channels, confirming the completion of the necessary internal legal procedures for this Memorandum to enter into force, as stipulated in both countries. This Memorandum shall remain valid for a period of three (3) years and shall be automatically renewed for one or more similar periods, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing, through diplomatic channels, of its desire to terminate it, at least three (3) months prior to its termination date or the expiry of its original term.

This Memorandum shall not be terminated or expire with respect to ongoing programs and activities until their completion, unless the Parties agree otherwise in writing.

In witness whereof, the undersigned plenipotentiaries, duly authorized by their respective governments, have signed this Memorandum.

# Memorandum of Understanding for Cooperation
## in the Field of Social Affairs between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the State of Qatar

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the "Ministry of Social Affairs <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig>", and the Government of the State of Qatar <orig>دولة قطر</orig>, represented by the "Ministry of Social Development and Family <orig>وزارة التنمية الاجتماعية والأسرة</orig>", hereinafter referred to as the two Parties.
Desiring to strengthen and consolidate the deep-rooted bonds of brotherhood between them, and to embody the common objectives between the two Parties in the field of social affairs.
They have agreed as follows:

### Article (1)
The two Parties shall work to exchange expertise, information, studies, and projects, and organize joint programs for qualification, training, and rehabilitation, and encourage creativity in the following areas of social affairs:
1. Social Security
2. Productive Family Affairs
3. Micro and Small Enterprises for Women as an entry point
4. What the two Parties deem appropriate in the field of daily social affairs for the following categories:
    a. Affairs of the Elderly and Persons with Disabilities.
    b. Community Services and Children of Unknown Parentage.
    c. Women, Child, and Girl Child Affairs.
5. Children's activities and projects that contribute to developing the role of civil society institutions
6. Supporting cooperation between civil society institutions working in the field of social affairs
7. Activating the resolutions of the Supreme Council of the Gulf Cooperation Council <orig>مجلس التعاون لدول الخليج العربية</orig> related to social affairs
8.

### Article 2
The two parties shall work on developing and qualifying means of joint cooperation in social affairs in both countries and prepare an annual plan that includes programs and activities ensuring cooperation.

### Article 3
Each party shall provide the other party with the opportunity to review its expertise and experiences in the field of social affairs and seek ways to benefit from them.

### Article 4
To achieve the objectives of this Memorandum and to ensure the activation of the areas of cooperation referred to in Article 1 thereof, the two parties shall undertake the following:
1) Exchange of delegation visits between the two countries to review their experiences in the field of social affairs.
2) Exchange of experts to implement the aforementioned programs.
3) Exchange of information, scientific publications, and electronic recommendations.
4) Organizing seminars, conferences, and joint activities related to social affairs between specialists in both countries.

### Article 5
A joint working team consisting of three (3) members from each country shall be formed to carry out the following tasks:
1) Ensuring the seriousness of the Memorandum.
2) Preparing activities and future project programs capable of implementing the Memorandum.
3) Periodically evaluating the performance of the Memorandum, reporting on the levels of program implementation, and reviewing any possible amendments to the Memorandum.

### Article (6)

1.  The accompanying party shall bear the travel and delegation expenses to and from the host country. The host party shall bear the expenses of accommodation, transportation, and emergency medical treatment for the other party, provided that such service is available.
2.  The organizing party shall bear all training expenses.
3.  The organizing party shall bear the cost of printing expenses, information dissemination, and training tools.

### Article (7)

This Memorandum shall not affect the obligations arising from bilateral, regional, and international agreements to which either party is a signatory.

### Article (8)

Both parties shall work to implement this Memorandum in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

### Article (9)

Any dispute arising from the interpretation and application of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably by both parties through diplomatic channels.

### Article (10)

1.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of the last written notification by which either party informs the other in writing, through diplomatic channels, of the completion of all necessary national legal procedures for its entry into force.
2.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in force for a period of five years, renewable in accordance with<image_caption>Official Seal of the State of Qatar</image_caption>

# Decree No. 86 of 2025
## Approving a Memorandum of Understanding
### Between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman <orig>سلطنة عمان</orig>
### Regarding Cooperation in the Land Transport Sector

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And Decree No. 84 of 2024 regarding Ministerial Substitutions and Delegations, and its amending decrees,
- And based on the presentation of the Minister of Foreign Affairs <orig>وزير الخارجية</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,

We have decreed the following:

### Article One
Approval of the Memorandum of Understanding between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman <orig>سلطنة عمان</orig> regarding cooperation in the land transport sector, signed in Kuwait City <orig>مدينة الكويت</orig> on 31 October 2024, the texts of which are attached to this Decree.

# Memorandum of Understanding Between
# The Government of the State of Kuwait
# And The Government of the Sultanate of Oman
# Regarding Cooperation in the Land Transport Sector

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the Public Authority for Roads and Land Transport <orig>الهيئة العامة للطرق والنقل البري</orig>, and the Government of the Sultanate of Oman, represented by the Ministry of Transport, Communications and Information Technology <orig>وزارة النقل والاتصالات وتقنية المعلومات</orig>, (hereinafter referred to as "the Parties").

Desiring to enhance the existing cooperation between the two countries on the basis of equality, reciprocity, and mutual benefit for the interest of both countries, and to work towards expanding cooperation in the field of land transport.

And in recognition of the Parties' readiness to share knowledge and expertise, including technical knowledge in the field of land transport, for the benefit of current and future endeavors alike, thereby achieving sustainable development, and affirming that this cooperation will serve common interests and contribute to strengthening sustainable bilateral cooperation in the field of land transport, in addition to creating a suitable and sustainable environment for competition by establishing that this cooperation will increase further economic and commercial exchange, and in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

Have agreed as follows:

## Article (1)

The Parties shall develop programs related to the land transport sector in which they have a mutual interest, through the following:
1- Establishing the legal foundations for cooperation in the field of land transport between the two countries.
2- Exchanging knowledge and academic cooperation, which involves capacity building and expertise.

State of Kuwait
For the Government of
Ali Al-Salem <orig>علي السالم</orig>
Minister of Asset Affairs <orig>وزير شؤون الأصول</orig>
3- Expanding the scope of technical cooperation between governmental institutions and companies in the field of land transport in both countries.
<page_end>219</page_end>

-4 Encouraging efforts to establish and develop direct cooperation relations between public and private institutions.
-5 Exchanging laws, provisions, and rules applied by both parties in the field of land transport.
-6 Exchanging visits of senior officials, experts, and consultants.
-7 Organizing joint seminars, conferences, and seasonal events on topics of common interest and other specific administrative activities.

The two parties may identify other areas of cooperation through diplomatic channels.

## Article (2)
The two parties shall implement all provisions of this Memorandum, evaluate and follow up on the cooperation activities stipulated in Article (1) of this Memorandum, and establish implementation procedures for any agreed-upon cooperative activity. Either party may determine the method of implementation within its affiliated institutions and companies.

## Article (3)
Each party shall treat with utmost confidentiality all exchanged information and documents and services provided in implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum. Neither party may disclose such information or documents to a third party except after obtaining prior written consent from the other party. This obligation shall continue for a period of (3) three years from the date of expiration or termination of this Memorandum.

## Article (4)
This Memorandum shall be implemented in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries, and in accordance with the principles of availability of funds and personnel from both parties.

## Article (6)
The Parties shall sign this Memorandum upon the approval of the government of each Party.

## Article (7)
Any disputes arising between the Parties concerning the interpretation or implementation of the provisions of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably between the Parties through consultations via diplomatic channels.

## Article (8)
The Parties may amend this Memorandum by agreement through diplomatic channels, and such amendment shall enter into force by the same procedures stipulated in paragraph 1 of Article 9.

## Article (9)
1.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the latter notification, in which one Party notifies the other Party, in writing and through diplomatic channels, of the fulfillment of the necessary constitutional procedures for its entry into force.
2.  This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in force for a period of 3 years from the date of its entry into force and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period, unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate this Agreement six (6) months prior to its expiry date.

# Memorandum of Understanding
# in
# the Field of Social Affairs
Between
# The Government of the State of Kuwait
And
# The Government of the Republic of Tunisia <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig>

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Republic of Tunisia <orig>الجمهورية التونسية</orig>,
In line with the fraternal ties that bind the two sisterly countries,
And out of their desire to strengthen and consolidate the bonds of Arab brotherhood between them, and in embodiment of the joint cooperation
between the two parties in the field of social affairs, the two parties have agreed as follows:

## Article One
The two parties shall work on exchanging expertise, information, studies, and legislation in the following fields:
1.  Productive Family Affairs
2.  Small and Medium Enterprises
3.  Social Welfare (Special Categories)
4.  Cooperative Societies
5.  Services for the Elderly and Children of Unknown Parentage
6.  Women and Family Affairs
7.  Youth Affairs
8.  The Role of the Private Sector and Civil Society Institutions in Activating the Role of Civil Society Institutions
9.  The Role of the Private Sector and Active Civil Society Institutions in the Field of Social Affairs
10. Preparation of Joint Studies Related to Social Affairs
### Article Two
The two parties shall work on changing and amending the means of joint cooperation in the fields of social affairs in both countries and adopting a partial plan for coordination on programs and activities that ensure the implementation of this protocol.

### Article Three
Each Party shall provide the other Party with an opportunity to review its expertise and experiences in the field of social law and to explore ways to benefit from them.

### Article Four
The authorities shall receive this Memorandum, and to ensure the facilitation of the areas of cooperation referred to in Article One, both Parties shall commit to the following:
- Exchange of delegation visits between technical experts to review their experiences in the field of social law.
- Exchange of experts for the exchange of joint programs between them and the appointment of representatives from both Parties.
- Exchange of information, technical consultations, and electronic software.
- Organization of joint courses, conferences, and activities related to social law between specialists in both countries.

### Article Five
A joint working team consisting of three members from each country shall be formed to discuss the following tasks:
- Ensuring their joint nature.
- Preparing activities and developing future programs necessary for the implementation of the Memorandum.
- Amending the provisions of this Memorandum, recommending any developments that may arise during implementation, and proposing a review or amendment regarding the provisions of this Memorandum.
- Reviewing and evaluating the extent of achievement of the Memorandum's provisions and submitting an annual report thereon to the Ministers of Social Affairs <orig>وزيري الشؤون الاجتماعية</orig> in both countries.
- The joint working team shall meet once a year, alternately in both countries, and whenever necessary.

### Article Six
The sending Party shall bear the travel expenses of a delegation to the host Party, round trip, and the host Party shall bear the expenses of accommodation, lodging, medical treatment, as well as related expenses in this regard.
- The host Party shall bear the expenses of the various mutual visits.
- The organizing Party shall bear all expenses for printing, disseminating information, and electronic documents.

### Article Eight
The two Parties shall implement this Memorandum in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

### Article Nine
Any dispute relating to the application or interpretation of this Memorandum shall be settled amicably by consultation between the two Parties through diplomatic channels.

### Article Ten
- This Memorandum of Understanding shall enter into force from the date of receipt of the last notification by which one Party informs the other Party of the completion of all its internal procedures necessary for the national procedures required for its entry into force.
- This Memorandum of Understanding shall remain in force for a period of two years from the date of its entry into force, and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods unless one Party notifies the other Party in writing and through diplomatic channels of its desire to terminate this Memorandum at least six (6) months prior to the expiry of the initial period or any subsequent period.
- This Memorandum may be amended by agreement of the two Parties, at any time, by preparing such amendments through the diplomatic channels mentioned in the first paragraph of this Article.
- The termination or amendment of this Memorandum shall not affect the validity of ongoing activities that have commenced implementation until their completion, unless the two Parties agree otherwise.

### Article Eleven
For the purpose of this Memorandum, the Memorandum of Understanding on Labor and Social Affairs, signed in the city of Tunis on May 20, 2016, was concluded.

<page_metadata>
