}
</page_metadata>
<header>
227
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1738, Seventy-First Year
Issue 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH - 11/5/2025 AD
</header>

Filed by Commercial Bank of Kuwait <orig>البنك التجاري الكويتي</orig>
Against Gulf Insurance Company <orig>شركة الخليج للتأمين</orig>

## Facts
Whereas the facts – as evident from the referral judgment and all other documents – indicate that the plaintiff bank (Commercial Bank of Kuwait <orig>البنك التجاري الكويتي</orig>) filed lawsuit No. (18492) of 2021 Commercial Plenary /32 against the defendant company (Gulf Insurance Company <orig>شركة الخليج للتأمين</orig>) seeking a judgment obliging it to pay the amount of (KWD 43,498.951) along with any accrued contractual interest at a rate of (3%) annually above the discount rate announced by the Central Bank <orig>البنك المركزي</orig> from the date of notification of payment on 6/10/2019 until the final settlement of the debt, on the grounds that, pursuant to a loan agreement dated 8/10/2018, Saeed Munif Saeed Al-Mutairi <orig>سعيد منيف سعيد المطيري</orig> obtained a personal loan of (KWD 42,000) deposited into his account with the bank, to be repaid in (180) monthly installments, each (KWD 355). However, on 18/1/2019, the said client passed away after settling part of the debt. Since the bank had insured the lives of its borrowers under a group insurance policy with the appellant company, and the insured risk materialized under that policy with the death of the borrowing client, leaving an outstanding amount of (KWD 43,498.951) from the principal loan and accrued interest, the bank notified the company's agent of payment on 6/10/2019, but it refused to pay, leading to the filing of the present lawsuit with the aforementioned requests.
At the session on 30/5/2023, the Court of First Instance ruled to dismiss the lawsuit. The plaintiff bank appealed this judgment under appeal No. (4231) of 2023 Commercial /19. The defendant company submitted a memorandum challenging the constitutionality of the third paragraph of Article (791) of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig>, regarding its provision obliging the insurer to pay the insurance amount and depriving them of the right to request annulment of the contract if the truth emerged after the risk materialized, without distinguishing between a good-faith insured and a bad-faith insured, in violation of Articles (7) and (8) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>. At the session on 9/1/2024, the Court of Appeal ruled to suspend consideration of the appeal and refer it to the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> to decide on the constitutionality of the third paragraph of Article (791) of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig>.
Following the arrival of the case file at the Registry Department <orig>إدارة كتاب</orig> of this Court, it was registered under No. (1) of 2024 "Constitutional", and the concerned parties were notified accordingly.
This Court heard the case at the session on 5/2/2025, as detailed in its minutes. The representative of the plaintiff submitted a memorandum concluding with a request for a judgment of inadmissibility of the lawsuit, and alternatively, its dismissal. The representative of the defendant submitted a memorandum concluding with a request for a judgment of unconstitutionality of the challenged text. The Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> submitted a memorandum in defense of the government, concluding with a request for a judgment of inadmissibility of the lawsuit, and alternatively, its dismissal. The Court decided to issue its judgment today.

## The Ruling
After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and deliberation.
Whereas the referral procedures have fulfilled their legally prescribed conditions.
Whereas Article (791) of the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> stipulates that: "1- An insurance contract shall be voidable in favor of the insurer if the insured remained silent about a matter or provided incorrect information, and this would change the subject of the risk or reduce its importance in the insurer's view.
2- If the truth is revealed before the risk materializes, the insurer may request the annulment of the contract ten days after notifying the insured by registered letter, unless the latter accepts an increase in the premium proportionate to the increase in the risk. The annulment of the contract in this case entails that the insurer returns the insurance premium or returns the portion for which no risk was borne.
3- However, if the truth emerges after the risk materializes, the insurance amount must be reduced by the ratio of the premiums actually paid to the premiums that should have been paid had the risks been correctly declared to the insurer."
Whereas the challenge to the third paragraph of the aforementioned Article – as indicated by the referral judgment – is that it equated the good-faith insured with the bad-faith insured in the event of providing incorrect data and the truth emerging after the risk materialized, as both are compensated without distinction according to the proportional rule, thereby depriving the insurer of their right to request the annulment of the contract, whereas the application of that rule should have been limited to the good-faith insured only, which violates Articles (7) and (8) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>.
Whereas this challenge is unfounded, as it is established – and as this Court's jurisprudence has held – that the discretionary power vested in the legislator according to
<page_end>227</page_end>

---

<page_start>228</page_start>
<page_metadata>
{
  "page_title": "Legal Analysis of Insurance Contract Regulations and Constitutional Review <orig>تحليل قانوني للوائح عقود التأمين والمراجعة الدستورية</orig>",
  "document_date": "2025-05-11",
  "issue_number": 1738,
  "volume_number": 71,
  "document_type": "legal_document",
  "languages_detected": ["ar"],
  "page_type": "content",
  "authors": null,
  "publisher": "Kuwait Today <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig>",
  "page_summary": "This page presents a legal analysis of insurance contract regulations in Kuwaiti civil law, specifically articles 773-809 and 790-791, discussing the balance between protecting the insured and the insurer's rights, risk disclosure, and the consequences of non-disclosure, concluding with a court's decision to reject a constitutional challenge."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1738 Seventy-First Year
228
Sunday 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH - 11/5/2025
</header>

This Court may not interfere in a matter that is inherently within the purview of the legislative authority in this manner, nor may it weigh, by its own subjective standards, the legislative policy adopted by the legislator on a specific subject, nor discuss it, nor delve into the practical appropriateness of its application, nor substitute its choices for those of the legislator, as long as it has been established that the legislator has exercised its competencies, inspired therein by purposes required by the public interest concerning the subject of legislative regulation.
Given this, and since the legislator regulated the insurance contract in the Civil Code <orig>القانون المدني</orig> in Articles (773) to (809), the texts of these articles – as clarified by the Explanatory Memorandum <orig>المذكرة الإيضاحية</orig> of the Law – collectively aim to protect the insured. Therefore, Article (808) thereof did not permit violating or amending its provisions unless it was in the interest of the insured or the beneficiary. In return, Article (790) of the Law placed obligations on the insured, including clearly stating, at the time of concluding the contract, all known circumstances that are important for the insurer to know to enable them to assess the risks they undertake, considering that the insured risk is the essential element in insurance. Article (791) specified the penalty for breaching this obligation if the insured remained silent about a matter or provided incorrect information, and this would change the subject of the risk or reduce its importance in the insurer's view. This penalty was made to be that the contract is voidable in the interest of the insurer, without differentiating between a good-faith insured and a bad-faith insured. However, the second paragraph of the article limited this penalty to the case where the truth is revealed before the risk materializes, allowing the insurer to request the annulment of the contract ten days after notifying the insured by registered letter, unless the latter accepts an increase in the premium proportionate to the increase in risk. The annulment of the contract in this case was not given retroactive effect – contrary to what general rules dictate – so the insurer remains obligated to guarantee the risk, and the insured remains obligated to pay premiums until the day the contract is annulled. The insurer is not obligated to refund any premiums received except for the amount for which no risk was borne. However, the insured can avert the request for annulment if they accept an increase in the premium proportionate to the increase in risk.
The third paragraph of Article (791) – the challenged provision – stipulated the penalty in the event that the truth did not emerge until after the risk materialized. In this case, it did not permit the insurer to request the annulment of the contract, because the risk had materialized, the contract was in force, and the insurer's obligation to guarantee became due. Thus, the insurer cannot be released from it by annulment, consistent with the nature of the annulment introduced by the legislator in this article, which only produces its effect for the future. However, since the premiums paid by the insured are not proportionate to the insured risk, the insurer only pays compensation proportionate to these premiums. Therefore, the legislator mandated a reduction in the insurance amount by a ratio of the premiums actually paid to the premiums that should have been paid if the risks had been correctly declared to the insurer, without differentiating between a bad-faith insured and a good-faith insured, which is the same approach followed by the legislator in determining the penalty of annulment. The legislator took into account that the insurer, as the stronger party in the insurance contract, has the right to include any conditions they wish in the insurance contract to define the scope of the insured risk and the conditions of its guarantee, and the insured only has the option to accept these conditions as long as they do not violate the law, in addition to the insurer's right to take all necessary measures to verify the accuracy of the data provided by the insured. If the contract was concluded according to the conditions set by the insurer, and after verifying the accuracy of the data provided by the insured, and the contract continued until the risk materialized and the inaccuracy of some of this data became apparent, then the legislator deemed it appropriate in this case to allow for the retention of the contract and the arrangement of its effects with a reduction in the insurance amount for which the insurer is liable, proportionate to that, and left the matter to the judiciary to estimate this ratio in a way that achieves justice between the two parties. Therefore, the legislative regulation envisioned by the legislator in this regard is not in violation of Articles (7) and (8) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>.
It goes without saying in this context that the judicial review exercised by this Court, which the legislator entrusted to it, does not extend to replacing a new ruling for the ruling contained in the challenged legislative text or supplementing its ruling with another ruling. Rather, its review is limited to taking the apparent meaning of the challenged text as a basis for examining its constitutionality, considering that the review of this Court is a constitutional review, not one of appropriateness. Furthermore, the presumption of constitutionality accompanying legislation assumes the conformity of legislative texts with the provisions of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>, and every possible presumption should be in favor of the legislation unless this presumption is rebutted by conclusive evidence that, by itself, definitively negates the constitutionality of the challenged text, which is not the case in the present constitutional lawsuit.
Accordingly, the lawsuit must be dismissed.
For these reasons
The Court ruled: to dismiss the lawsuit.
Session Secretary
Chief Justice
<page_end>228</page_end>

<header>

</header>

Presided over by His Excellency Counselor / Adel Ali Al-Bahou <orig>عادل علي البحـو</orig>, President of the Court
And with the membership of Their Excellencies Counselors /
Saleh Khalifa Al-Murshed <orig>صالح خليفه المرشد</orig> and Abdul Rahman Mishari Al-Darmi <orig>عبد الرحمن مشاري الدارمي</orig>
and Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Al-Saif <orig>إبراهيم عبد الرحمن السيف</orig> and Walid Ibrahim Al-Moajel <orig>وليد إبراهيم المعجل</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. / Yousef Ahmed Ma'rafi <orig>يوسف أحمد معرفي</orig>, Session Secretary
The following judgment was issued:
In the case registered in the Constitutional Court's register under No. (2) for the year
2024 "Constitutional"
After the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig> referred appeals Nos. (3978),
(3981), and (4061) for the year 2023, Administrative Contracts and Individual Appeals/4,
filed by:
Essam Abdul Samad Mohammed Al-Saleh <orig>عصام عبد الصمد محمد الصالح</orig> on his own behalf and in his capacity as Chairman of the Board of Directors of the
Union of Private Medical Professions Owners <orig>اتحاد أصحاب المهن الطبية الأهلية</orig>
Against:
1 – Undersecretary of the Ministry of Health <orig>وكيل وزارة الصحة</orig> in his capacity. 2 – Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig> in his capacity.
3 – Secretary-General of the Council of Ministers <orig>الأمين العام لمجلس الوزراء</orig> in his capacity. 4 – Minister of Health <orig>وزير الصحة</orig> in his capacity.

The Facts
Whereas the summary of the facts – as evident from the referral judgment and all other
documents – is that the plaintiff (Essam Abdul Samad Mohammed Al-Saleh <orig>عصام عبد الصمد محمد الصالح</orig> on his own behalf
and in his capacity) filed case No. (8080) for the year
2022, Administrative Plenary/6, against the defendants, requesting a judgment to suspend the enforcement and annul Ministerial Resolution
No. (196) for the year 2022, dated 17/5/2022, to consider it
null and void, and to cancel all its resulting effects. This was based on the assertion that the
Minister of Health <orig>وزير الصحة</orig> issued the aforementioned challenged resolution, published in the
Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> on 29/5/2022, obliging private medical sector institutions
to treat medical waste resulting from their operations at the medical waste treatment unit
affiliated with the Ministry and through contracting with the company assigned
by the Ministry. The resolution also prohibited granting or renewing health licenses for all
private medical sector institutions unless a certificate proving a contract with that company was submitted.
Since this resolution contradicts the constitutionally protected right to property,
and violates the provisions of Law No. (72) for the year 2020 regarding competition
protection, by restricting free competition, as well as Law No. (70)
for the year 2020 regarding the practice of medicine, allied professions, patient rights,
and health facilities, which stipulated in Article (56) thereof that
private medical sector institutions must safely dispose of medical waste
without limiting this to contracting with a specific company. Furthermore, the resolution was flawed
by an abuse of authority for specifying exorbitant costs for contracting with
the company assigned by the Ministry, which would harm the interests of
medical sector institutions. Therefore, the Union of Private Medical Professions Owners <orig>اتحاد أصحاب المهن الطبية الأهلية</orig>,
represented by the plaintiff, appealed the resolution without success, which led him
to file his lawsuit with the aforementioned requests.
At the session on 28/11/2023, the court of first instance ruled to dismiss the case.
The plaintiff appealed this judgment with appeals Nos. (3978), (3981),
and (4061) for the year 2023, Administrative Contracts and Individual Appeals/4, and argued the unconstitutionality
of the challenged resolution. At the session on 25/4/2024, the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig>
decided to suspend consideration of the appeals and refer them to the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig>
to rule on the constitutionality of Articles (1), (2), and (3) of the resolution and Table
No. (1) attached thereto, regarding the imposition of a fee for the treatment of medical waste,
medicines, and consumables, in violation of Article (134) of the Constitution.
Following the receipt of the case file by the Registry Department of this Court, it was registered in
its records under No. (2) for the year 2024 "Constitutional," and the concerned
parties were notified accordingly.
This Court considered the case at the session on 5/2/2025, as detailed
in its minutes. The plaintiff appeared in person, and those present with him submitted three
memoranda, each concluding with a request for a judgment on the unconstitutionality of the challenged ministerial
resolution. The Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> submitted a memorandum in defense of the government,
requesting at its conclusion a judgment to dismiss the case. The Court decided to issue its
judgment today.

The Court
After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and deliberation.
Whereas the referral procedures have fulfilled their legally prescribed conditions.
Whereas the challenged Ministerial Resolution No. (196) for the year 2022,
issued on 17/5/2022 – and published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> on
29/5/2022 – stipulates in its Article (1) that "It is prohibited to grant,
issue, or renew health licenses for all types and specializations of healthcare
facilities, pharmaceutical factories, warehouses, companies,
and pharmacies in the private medical sector, except after submitting a certificate
issued by the Hotel Services Department <orig>إدارة الخدمات الفندقية</orig> and approved by the Environmental Audit Department <orig>إدارة التدقيق البيئي</orig>
of the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig>, confirming a contract with the company assigned to manage, operate,
and maintain the Kabad 3 Medical Waste Treatment Plant <orig>محطة معالجة النفايات الطبية كبد 3</orig> affiliated with the Ministry of Health
for the treatment of their medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables.
A grace period of (30) days is granted after the publication of the resolution in the Official Gazette
for those who obtained licenses before the issuance of the resolution to submit the certificate."
Article (2) of the resolution stipulates that: "The duration of the medical waste treatment contract
for healthcare facilities, pharmaceutical factories, warehouses,
companies, and pharmacies in the private medical sector must be the same as the duration
granted for the license, according to regulatory and ministerial decisions."
Article (3) thereof stipulates that: "The cost of treating medical waste,
medicines, and medical consumables shall not exceed the maximum limit stipulated in Annex No. 1
attached to the resolution."
Annex No. (1) attached to the aforementioned resolution specifies the prescribed costs
<page_end>229</page_end>

<header>
230
Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH / 11/5/2025 AD
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue No. 1738, Seventy-First Year
</header>
<table>

|:--|:---|:---|:---|:---|
| 1 | Private Hospital <orig>مستشفى أهلي</orig> | 600,000 | 7,500 | 100,000 |
| 2 | Private Clinic / Center <orig>مستوصف / مركز أهلي</orig> | 300,000 | 3,750 | 100,000 |
| 3 | Individual Clinic <orig>عيادة فردية</orig> | 50,000 | 0,750 | 100,000 |

Rather, it may change depending on the nature of the transactions in terms of their volume, quantity, or performance circumstances.
Given that, and it being established that the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> had entrusted one of the private companies – by virtue of the contract concluded with it after the tender was awarded – with the management, operation, and maintenance of its medical waste treatment plant, and based on that, the Minister of Health <orig>وزير الصحة</orig> issued the contested Ministerial Decision <orig>القرار الوزاري المطعون فيه</orig> which prohibited the granting, issuance, or renewal of health licenses for all types and specializations of therapeutic health facilities, as well as pharmaceutical factories, warehouses, companies, and pharmacies in the private medical sector <orig>القطاع الطبي الأهلي</orig>, except after submitting a certificate from the competent administration confirming a contract with that company for the treatment of their medical waste, medicines, and medical consumables, provided that the contract duration is the same as the duration granted for the license, and it was not permissible for the cost of treating the medical waste, medicines, and consumables agreed upon in that contract to exceed the upper limit stated in the annex attached to the decision. Therefore, what the decision contained regarding the cost of treating the aforementioned waste is not considered a fee, as it is not a fixed amount that all health facilities are obligated to pay, but rather it is estimated according to purely economic considerations that take into account the nature and quantity of the waste to be treated. The reality of this cost lies in the service requested by the medical facility from the company commissioned by the Ministry of Health <orig>وزارة الصحة</orig> to manage a plant for treating its waste, and thus it does not fall within the concept of fees, which can only be established within the limits of the law. Furthermore, the contested decision <orig>القرار المطعون فيه</orig> did not impose a specific charge on health facilities that they are obligated to pay to that company, but rather set an upper limit that may not be exceeded in the contract concluded between the two parties. Consequently, the claim that the contested decision <orig>القرار المطعون فيه</orig> imposed a fee on health facilities in violation of Article (134) of the Constitution <orig>المادة (134) من الدستور</orig> is without valid basis, and therefore the lawsuit must be dismissed.

And since it is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the scope of the constitutional lawsuit <orig>الدعوى الدستورية</orig> is determined by the scope of the plea of unconstitutionality raised before the trial court <orig>محكمة الموضوع</orig>, and within the limits in which that court assesses its seriousness, therefore the Court disregards the reasons for the plea of unconstitutionality of the contested decision <orig>القرار المطعون فيه</orig> that the plaintiff presented in his memoranda, and confines itself to what the trial court <orig>محكمة الموضوع</orig> stated as an objection to that decision in the referral judgment <orig>حكم الإحالة</orig> without exceeding that scope.
And since the basis of the objection to the aforementioned articles of the contested Ministerial Decision <orig>قرار وزير الصحة المطعون فيه</orig> and its attached table – as evident from the referral judgment <orig>حكم الإحالة</orig> – is that the correct classification of the amounts listed in the table attached to the contested decision <orig>القرار المطعون فيه</orig> is that they are in reality (a fee prescribed for benefiting from the services of the medical waste treatment unit resulting from the private medical sector <orig>القطاع الطبي الأهلي</orig>), and that the decision thereby imposed a fee for the treatment of medical waste, medicines, and consumables in violation of Article (134) of the Constitution <orig>المادة (134) من الدستور</orig>, which does not permit the imposition of fees except within the limits of the law, meaning that the government's authority to impose fees can only be through a law that authorizes it to exercise this authority, otherwise its imposition would be unconstitutional.
And since this objection is rebutted, the import of Article (134) of the Constitution <orig>المادة (134) من الدستور</orig> is that no one may be charged with paying fees except within the limits of the law. What is meant by fees is what a public authority imposes in exchange for specific services it provides to those who request them, and their estimation does not take into account the cost of the service, as their amount is generally fixed for all beneficiaries of these services, throughout the validity of the legislative instrument that imposed them. In this way, they differ from the price or service charge collected by authorities managing state property <orig>أملاك الدولة</orig>, as this price or charge is paid to an economic public utility managed by an authority according to economic management methods, and it is determined according to purely economic criteria, and may be subject to changes imposed by the nature of economic conditions, and may be subject to changes resulting from negotiation between the product or service requester and the economic utility.

<footer>
For these reasons,
The Court ruled: to dismiss the lawsuit.
Session Secretary Court President
</footer>
<page_end>230</page_end>

Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH / May 11, 2025 AD

# The Constitutional Court / Al-Hikma Al-Dusturiya <orig>الحكمة الدستورية</orig>
## Consultation Chamber / Ghorfat Al-Mashoura <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>

At the session held by the Court in the Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH, corresponding to April 30, 2025 AD
Presided over by His Excellency Counselor <orig>المستشار</orig> / Adel Ali Al-Bahwa <orig>عادل علي البحوه</orig>, President of the Court <orig>رئيس الحكمة</orig>
And with the membership of Their Excellencies Counselors <orig>المستشارين</orig>
Saleh Khalifa Al-Murshed <orig>صالح خليفه المرشد</orig> and Abdul Rahman Mishari Al-Darmi <orig>عبد الرحمن مشاري الدارمي</orig>
and Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Al-Saif <orig>إبراهيم عبد الرحمن السيف</orig> and Waleed Ibrahim Al-Moajel <orig>وليد إبراهيم المعجل</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. / Yousef Ahmed Ma'rafi <orig>يوسف أحمد معرفي</orig>, Session Secretary <orig>أمين سر الجلسة</orig>

### The following decision was issued:

In Direct Appeal / Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>
Registered in the Court's <orig>الحكمة</orig> register under number (13) for the year 2024
Filed by:
The legal representative of Al-Muzaini Exchange Company <orig>شركة المزيني للصيرفة</orig>
The Court <orig>الحكمة</orig>

After reviewing the documents and deliberation.

Whereas the appellant company <orig>الشركة الطاعنة</orig> challenged the unconstitutionality of Article (34), paragraph (1) of Law No. (72) of 2020 concerning competition protection, and Articles (48), (49), and (50) of Resolution No. (14) of 2021 regarding the issuance of the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of the Law, arguing that Article (34), paragraph (1) of the Law overlooked the principle of proportionality between the violation and the penalty or sanction prescribed for it. This is because imposing a financial penalty on the violating person at a rate not exceeding (10%) of the total revenues achieved during the fiscal year preceding the violation constitutes a financial penalty characterized by exaggeration, excessiveness, and disproportionality with the committed violation and its resulting effects. There is no connection between it and the activity for which the violation was committed, as it extends to include all revenues of the violator, regardless of their relation to that violation, which confirms the harshness, excessiveness, and injustice of this financial penalty. Furthermore, this article also violated the principle of equality by allowing the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> to impose different financial penalties on perpetrators of the same violation, in contravention of Articles (7), (8), and (29) of the Constitution. As for the challenged articles of the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig>, they made the decisions of the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> enforceable immediately upon their issuance, and in case of non-compliance, the Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Authority <orig>رئيس مجلس إدارة الجهاز</orig> shall submit a report to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> in this regard, despite the Law not including such provisions. This means that it has thereby introduced crimes not stipulated in the Law, in contravention of Article (32) of the Constitution. The appellant had a direct personal interest in filing the present appeal, as Disciplinary Council <orig>المجلس التأديبي</orig> Decision No. (3) of 2024 was issued on 2024/7/10, fining it 3% of the total revenues it achieved during the previous fiscal year, for violating Article (5/a) of the aforementioned Law No. (72) of 2020, which prompted the filing of the present appeal.

Whereas it is established - in the jurisprudence of this Court <orig>هذه المحكمة</orig> - that the litigation in a direct appeal, like all constitutional litigations, is an objective litigation originally directed at the challenged legislative text for unconstitutionality. Its essence is the jurisdiction over that text itself, aiming to monitor it and verify its compliance with the Constitution. The legislative text, in this respect, is the subject and locus of the litigation, to which it is directed and by whose scope it is defined.

And whereas this Court <orig>هذه المحكمة</orig>, in its session held on 2025/2/5, ruled in Appeal No. (5) of 2023, a "Direct Constitutional Appeal <orig>طعن مباشر دستوري</orig>", "on the unconstitutionality of paragraph (1) of Article (34) of Law No. (72) of 2020 concerning competition protection, regarding its provision for imposing financial penalties not exceeding ten percent (10%) of the total revenues achieved by the concerned person during the preceding fiscal year in case of violating the provisions of Articles (5), (6), (7), and (8) of this Law." And since the appellant's present appeal was directed at the same aforementioned article, aiming for a ruling on its unconstitutionality, the litigation in this appeal consequently becomes moot, its subject matter having ceased to exist and its cause having vanished, as that ruling effectively fulfilled the appellant's requests. As for the challenge to the articles of the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> related to the implementation of financial penalties, it also became without merit after the disappearance of the text that stipulates these penalties. Therefore, the constitutional litigation in the appeal - under these circumstances - is concluded, which must be declared.

### Therefore,

The Court, in the Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>, decided the termination of the litigation in the appeal.

Session Secretary <orig>أمين السر</orig>
President of the Court <orig>رئيس الحكمة</orig>
# Consultation Chamber / Ghorfat Al-Mashoura <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>

At the session held by the Court in the Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig> on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah
1446 AH, corresponding to April 30, 2025 AD
Presided over by His Excellency Counselor <orig>المستشار</orig> / Adel Ali Al-Bahwa <orig>عادل علي البحو</orig>, President of the Court <orig>رئيس المحكمة</orig>
And with the membership of Their Excellencies Counselors <orig>المستشارين</orig> /
Saleh Khalifa Al-Murshed <orig>صالح خليفه المرشد</orig> and Abdul Rahman Mishari Al-Darmi <orig>عبد الرحمن مشاري الدارمي</orig>
and Ibrahim Abdul Rahman Al-Saif <orig>إبراهيم عبد الرحمن السيف</orig> and Waleed Ibrahim Al-Moajel <orig>وليد إبراهيم المعجل</orig>
And in the presence of Mr. / Yousef Ahmed Ma'rafi <orig>يوسف أحمد معرفي</orig>, Session Secretary <orig>أمين سر الجلسة</orig>

## The following decision was issued:

In Direct Appeal / Consultation Chamber <orig>غرفة المشورة</orig>
Registered in the Court's <orig>المحكمة</orig> register under number (14) for the year 2024

### Filed by:

The legal representative of Al-Mulla International Exchange Company <orig>شركة الملا العالمية للصرافة</orig>

## The Ruling

After reviewing the documents and deliberation.

Whereas the appellant company <orig>الشركة الطاعنة</orig> challenged the unconstitutionality of Article (34), paragraph (1) of Law No. (72) of 2020 concerning Competition Protection <orig>قانون حماية المنافسة</orig>, and Articles (48), (49), and (50) of Resolution No. (14) of 2021 regarding the issuance of the Executive Regulations of the Law <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية للقانون</orig>, arguing that Article (34), paragraph (1) of the Law violated the principle of proportionality between the violation and the prescribed penalty or sanction. This is because imposing a financial penalty <orig>جزاء مالي</orig> on the violating person at a rate not exceeding (10%) of the total revenues achieved during the preceding fiscal year constitutes a financial penalty characterized by exaggeration, excessiveness, and disproportionality with the committed violation and its resulting effects. There is no link between it and the activity for which the violation was committed, as it extends to include all revenues of the violator, regardless of their relation to that violation, which confirms the harshness, excessiveness, and injustice of this financial penalty. Furthermore, this article also violated the principle of equality, as it allowed the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> to impose different financial penalties on perpetrators of the same violation, in contravention of Articles (7), (8), and (29) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>. As for the challenged articles of the Executive Regulations, they made the decisions of the Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> enforceable immediately upon their issuance, and in case of non-compliance, the Head of the Authority's administration <orig>رئيس إدارة الجهاز</orig> would submit a report to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> in this regard, despite the Law not including such provisions. Thus, it introduced crimes not stipulated in the Law, in contravention of Article (32) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>. The appellant had a direct personal interest <orig>مصلحة شخصية مباشرة</orig> in submitting its present appeal, as Disciplinary Council <orig>مجلس التأديب</orig> Decision No. (3) of 2024 was issued on 10/7/2024, fining it (5%) of the total revenues it achieved during the preceding fiscal year, for violating Article (5) of the aforementioned Law No. (72) of 2020, which prompted it to submit its present appeal.
Whereas it is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court <orig>قضاء هذه المحكمة</orig> – that litigation in a direct appeal <orig>الطعن المباشر</orig>, like all constitutional litigations <orig>الخصومات الدستورية</orig>, is an objective litigation <orig>خصومة عينية</orig> primarily directed at the legislative text challenged for unconstitutionality. Its essence is the jurisdiction over that text itself, aiming to monitor it and verify its compliance with the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>. The legislative text, in this regard, is the subject and object of the litigation, to which it is directed and by whose scope it is defined.
Whereas this Court ruled in its session held on 5/2/2025 in Appeal No. (5) of 2023, a "direct constitutional appeal <orig>طعن مباشر دستوري</orig>", on "the unconstitutionality of paragraph (1) of Article (34) of Law No. (72) of 2020 concerning Competition Protection <orig>قانون حماية المنافسة</orig>, insofar as it included the imposition of financial penalties not exceeding ten percent (10%) of the total revenues achieved by the concerned person during the preceding fiscal year in case of violating the provisions of Articles (5), (6), (7), and (8) of this Law", and the appellant's present appeal was directed at the same aforementioned article, aiming for a ruling on its unconstitutionality. Consequently, the litigation in this appeal becomes moot, as a result of the disappearance of its subject matter and the cessation of its cause, that judgment leading to the fulfillment of the appellant's requests. As for the appeal against the articles of the Executive Regulations related to the implementation of financial penalties, it has also become moot after the disappearance of the text that stipulates these penalties. Therefore, the constitutional litigation in the appeal – under these circumstances – is terminated, which must be declared.

## Therefore

The Court, in its deliberation chamber, decided the termination of the litigation in the appeal.

  "page_summary": "This page details a ruling by the Kuwaiti Constitutional Court concerning an appeal against a lower court's decision regarding the constitutionality of Article 125 of Law No. 7 of 2010, which penalizes false claims against the Capital Markets Authority. The court ultimately rejected the appeal on its merits."
}
</page_metadata>
<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1738, Seventy-First Year
233
Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH / 11/5/2025 AD
</header>

During the court sessions, the appellant submitted a memorandum arguing the unconstitutionality of what is contained in Article (125) of Law No. (7) of 2010, which punishes "any person who claimed – contrary to the truth – that the Authority had taken any measure or decision that it had not actually taken," due to the failure to definitively specify the criminalized acts, which prevents their confusion with others, in violation of Articles (30), (32), and (36) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>.
At the session on 16/9/2024, the court of the challenged judgment ruled that the plea of unconstitutionality was not serious, and punished the appellant by fining him five thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig> for the accusation attributed to him.
As the appellant was not satisfied with the ruling of the latter judgment regarding the non-seriousness of the plea of unconstitutionality, he appealed it before the Appeals Examination Committee of the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> with a petition filed with the Registry Department of this Court on 13/10/2024, where it was registered under number (7) for the year 2024. At the conclusion of that petition, he requested the annulment of the judgment issued regarding the non-seriousness of the plea of unconstitutionality, and the referral of the matter to the Constitutional Court <orig>المحكمة الدستورية</orig> – in its full composition – for a decision.
This Court considered the appeal at the session on 5/2/2025, as indicated in the session minutes. The appellant appeared in person, submitted a portfolio of documents, and insisted on his requests contained in the appeal petition. The representative of the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> submitted a memorandum requesting at its conclusion a judgment rejecting the appeal. The representative of the Fatwa and Legislation Department <orig>إدارة الفتوى والتشريع</orig> submitted a memorandum requesting at its conclusion, primarily, a judgment of inadmissibility of the appeal, and secondarily, its rejection. The Court decided to issue the judgment on the appeal at today's session.

## The Judgment

After reviewing the documents, hearing the pleadings, and deliberation.
Whereas the appeal has fulfilled its legally prescribed conditions.
Whereas the appellant faults the challenged judgment for insufficiency of reasoning and corruption in inference, as it ruled on the unconstitutionality of the scope of what is contained in Article (125) of Law No. (7) of 2010 regarding the punishment of "any person who claimed – contrary to the truth – that the Authority had taken any measure or decision that it had not actually taken," despite the fact that it is touched by a suspicion of unconstitutionality due to the failure to definitively specify the criminalized acts, which prevents their confusion with others, in violation of Articles (30), (32), and (36) of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>.
Whereas this objection is rebutted by what is established – in the jurisprudence of this Court – that the assessment of the seriousness of the plea of unconstitutionality requires the convergence of two necessary matters: first, that the decision on the constitutional matter is necessary for deciding the substantive dispute; and second, that there is an apparent suspicion of the legislative text subject to the plea violating the provisions of the Constitution <orig>الدستور</orig>.
Given this, and since the legislator, by virtue of the challenged text of the aforementioned Law No. (7) of 2010, punished "any person who claimed – contrary to the truth – that the Authority had taken any measure or decision that it had not actually taken," the text was clear in defining the material element required for this crime, which is the performance of a positive act consisting of claiming that the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة أسواق المال</orig> took a measure or decision related to its activity exercised in accordance with the provisions of this law, and that it is proven that it did not actually take this measure or decision; if it had actually taken it, the material element of the crime would not be realized. And since this crime is an intentional crime, this act must be accompanied by criminal intent, which is the perpetrator's will and intention to alter the truth by attributing actions to the Authority that it did not perform, with his knowledge of that. The burden of proof for the existence of the crime with its elements, as stated above, lies with the prosecution authority, and the Court is also obligated to verify this itself in light of its assessment of the evidence presented to it. Consequently, the objection to the challenged text regarding the lack of clarity and definition of the criminalized acts, which could lead to their confusion with other acts, is a claim not based on a sound foundation. And since the challenged judgment concluded that the plea of unconstitutionality was not serious, it has reached a correct conclusion, and the appeal against it is therefore not based on a sound foundation, and thus it must be ruled to reject it and obligate the appellant to pay the costs.

### For these reasons
The Court ruled: to accept the appeal formally, reject it substantively, and obligate the appellant to pay the costs.

Session Secretary
Presiding Judge
</footer>

<header>
235
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1738, Seventy-First Year
Sunday, 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH - 11/5/2025 AD

and his undertaking to commit to repaying the debt owed to the bank, for which these banking facilities were arranged. Accordingly, the bank did not properly (or nominally) act in the company with a grace period under official amendment contract No. 2019/3195 dated 22/9/2019. However, this partner did not fulfill his undertaking to repay the value of the banking facilities, causing the disruption of the applicant company's interests and its involvement in legal disputes. This incurred significant disagreement due to its irregularities, and this partner caused the removal of the company's owner and its actual manager, Mr. Ibrahim Abdel Nabi Al-Shirazi <orig>إبراهيم عبد النبي الشيرازي</orig>, by a judicial instrument, which led to the manager's authority being removed from the company's management and the cessation of its operations and activities. In a serious attempt by the company to salvage the situation with the nominal partners in order to manage the company's affairs and fulfill its obligations towards third parties, an agreement was reached with him under an official agreement contract dated 1/3/2021, in which he undertook to be the fourth party responsible for repaying the loan owed to the bank, its predecessor (the banking facilities contract). The contract was not submitted in one of the lawsuits provided with a grace period, and the agreement was appended with the executive formula in lawsuit No. 2006/1552 Commercial Plenary. Based on this judgment, the applicant company sent a letter to the bank to provide a payment guarantee from Hassan Ali Mohammed Haja <orig>حسن علي محمد حاجة</orig>, with his undertaking to bear the debt and commit to repayment, and the bank, its predecessor, accepted these interests. However, the aforementioned did not adhere to what he undertook in the settlement agreement. After its suffering with the nominal partner, the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> ruled on 14/3/2023 in appeal No. 2023/333 Commercial / 1 regarding the nominality of the official company amendment contract dated 2019/3159, which is the company amendment contract under which this nominal partner entered the applicant company. This judgment heralds the return of the applicant company to its former state of carrying out its activities and fulfilling all its obligations, which prompted it to approach the bank, its predecessor, to conduct an amicable settlement regarding the outstanding debt by virtue of the assignment of debt <orig>حوالة الدين</orig> which the bank, its predecessor, accepted and which is still pending before the judiciary. However, the bank, its predecessor, did not facilitate the loyal parties in that lawsuit, and initiated enforcement procedures against the guarantors, especially Arkan Financial Company (Oman) <orig>شركة أركان المالية (عمان)</orig>.

Ali Mohammed Hajja <orig>حسن علي محمد حاجة</orig> against the Applicant Company and others, requesting the appointment of an expert to determine his share of the Applicant Company's profits and shares, and from the minutes of the extraordinary general assembly meeting of the Applicant Company, and from judgment no. 2020/1552, Commercial Plenary/19, which ruled to reject the settlement agreement dated 01/03/2021 in its bankruptcy report, the content of which is established therein and made enforceable, and from the judgment issued on 08/01/2023 in appeal no. 2022/3990, Commercial Civil Government/1, and from the judgment issued on 14/01/2023 in cassation appeal no. 2022/3233, Commercial/1, which ruled to accept the appeal formally and, on the merits, to partially distinguish the appealed judgment regarding its decision to reject appeal no. 2022/105 (Appellate) concerning its decision to reject the original lawsuit and to rule on the fictitious nature of the amendment contract of Arcada United General Trading and Contracting Company <orig>شركة أركادا المتحدة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig>, notarized under number 2019/3159 (Contracts and Companies) dated Whereas the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued his decision on 3/9/2023 to address the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> to provide an opinion on the current request, the Committee's opinion was received, including its decision in Report No. (2023/8) dated 11/9/2023, which concluded, based on the available documents, that the debtor's <orig>المدين</orig> situation indicates the possibility of continuing its operations and its ability to repay its outstanding debts if the preventive settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig> is accepted.

On 17/9/2023, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued a decision to commence preventive settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig> procedures regarding the request submitted by the debtor (Arcada United General Trading and Contracting Company <orig>شركة أركادا المتحدة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig>), with the suspension of all judicial claims and enforcement procedures taken against it for a period of three months from the date of the current request, as detailed in its operative part.

Based on the applicant company's <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> request in its letter dated 18/10/2023, in which it outlined the negotiations and consultations with the opposing bank <orig>البنك المقدم ضده</orig> regarding the preventive settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig>, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued a decision on 20/12/2023 to set the duration for the suspension of judicial claims and enforcement procedures taken against the applicant company <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> and pending between the parties to the current request for a period of one month from the date of the decision, as detailed in its operative part.

Decision Issued Regarding Real Estate Registration Applications

Based on this decision, Kuwait Municipality / Baladiyat Al-Kuwait <orig>بلدية الكويت</orig> issued its letter dated 5/9/2024, registered under reference number [INT-6305-44-2024-00363], which concluded that a description certificate for the property subject of the previous decision could not be issued due to existing violations, and these violations were not mentioned in the aforementioned letter.

On 22/9/2024, the representative of the applicant company attended and submitted a letter requesting the issuance of a decision by the Assistant Undersecretary for Real Estate Registration and Documentation Affairs - Ministry of Justice / Wizarat Al-Adl <orig>وزارة العدل</orig> - to release the property's ownership, Bond Document No. (547) Guarantee, without the need to issue a description certificate, in accordance with the undertakings established in the application, due to the inability to obtain a description certificate. Attached to the application were copies of Bond Document No. (547) and the technical bank's undertaking to finance the purchase of the property for the buyer.

On 6/10/2024, Mr. Sayed Abdul Razzaq Sayed Adnan Al-Zuwaili <orig>سيد عبدالرزاق سيد عدنان الزويلي</orig>, the attorney for the opposing bank, attended and stated that the bank has no objection to the applicant company pursuing the implementation procedures of the preventive settlement agreement at an appropriate time, while enabling it to complete the sale of the mortgaged property in favor of the bank, in execution of the proposal.

At the conclusion of the session on 9/10/2024, the Bankruptcy Judge issued a decision authorizing the applicant company (Arkan United General Trading and Contracting Company <orig>شركة أركان المتحدة للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig>) before the Real Estate Registration and Documentation Department at the Ministry of Justice / Wizarat Al-Adl <orig>وزارة العدل</orig> to sell its owned property located in Al-Jahra <orig>الجهراء</orig> area - Plot (4) - Parcel (103), hexagonal plan No. (31541), and registered under Document No. (547) Guarantee, after obtaining the approval of the opposing bank to release the Gulf (mortgaged financial asset), and without the need to issue a property description certificate or a property identification certificate, provided that the existing violations on the property are comprehensively mentioned, and that the buyer submits an undertaking to remove any violations within a reasonable period from the date of title transfer, and that both the buyer and seller submit an undertaking not to recourse against any ministry or government body as a result of the property's ownership release. All of this is for the purpose of releasing its ownership to the buyer by registering the sale contract and extracting the bond document as stated above, provided that this is at
<footer>
the responsibility (1) of the Bankruptcy Supervisor for the accuracy of the submitted data and whether it is correct according to the provisions of the law.
</footer>
### Date of Publication of Liquidation and Bankruptcy Announcement

The urgency is a right claimed by the applicant company, stating the preventive settlement proposal for which the application was submitted. The Bankruptcy Department must notify the General Department of Execution, the Real Estate Registration and Documentation Departments at the Ministry of Justice / Wizarat Al-Adl <orig>وزارة العدل</orig>, Kuwait Municipality / Baladiyat Al-Kuwait <orig>بلدية الكويت</orig>, the applicant company, and the opposing bank of this decision, with the executive formula affixed thereto in accordance with the procedures stipulated in the Bankruptcy Law.

## Orders of the Bankruptcy Judge

On 16/12/2024, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued a decision authorizing the bank against which the application was filed to disburse the amount of
K.D. 3,320,000/- deposited under Execution File No. (2293470.12), in implementation of the approved preventive settlement proposal, as stated in the operative part of the decision.

On 11/2/2025, Mr. Ahmed Al-Sabagh <orig>أحمد الصباغ</orig>, the lawyer for the bank against which the application was filed, appeared by virtue of a special power of attorney bearing No. 2024/14519 Al-Jahra <orig>الجهراء</orig> - Court Mall. On the same date, the applicant company submitted the preventive settlement proposal in accordance with the preventive settlement proposal approved by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>. He submitted a portfolio of documents containing photocopies of a banking facilities contract, a mortgage secured by real estate, a joint and several personal guarantee, and a waiver of previous contracts dated 25/1/2020, bearing No. 699, Saleh's Dream, to which reference is made, and checks No. (169893) dated 25/1/2025, drawn on Al-Ahli Bank <orig>البنك الأهلي</orig>, issued from the account of the General Department of Execution <orig>الإدارة العامة للتنفيذ</orig> for an amount of K.D. 330,000/- (that thirty thousand Kuwaiti Dinars) payable to the beneficiary, the bank against which the application was filed (Gulf Bank <orig>بنك الخليج</orig>), and checks No. (0360964) issued on 13/1/2025, drawn on Kuwaiti Al-Ahli Bank <orig>البنك الأهلي الكويتي</orig> for an amount of K.D. 900,000/- (one million nine hundred thousand Kuwaiti Dinars) in favor of the bank against which the application was filed (Gulf Bank <orig>بنك الخليج</orig>).

The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> instructed the applicant company to attend the headquarters of the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> to provide a response regarding the implementation of the preventive settlement proposal and for its agent to be examined by the department on 13/2/2025. Based on its request, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> postponed the consideration of the application and instructed the applicant company to submit the necessary notification indicating the implementation of the preventive settlement proposal and its supporting documents at the earliest session.

On 8/4/2025, the representative of the applicant company appeared and submitted a letter containing the applicant company's notification of the implementation of the preventive settlement proposal. The letter concluded with a request to issue a decision to terminate the preventive settlement procedures. Attached to the letter were photocopies of documents indicating the implementation of the proposal, including (1) a photocopy of check No. (586147) dated 3/6/2024, drawn on Gulf Bank <orig>بنك الخليج</orig> for an amount of K.D. 980,000.

# Amendment to the Bankruptcy Judge's Decision

Based on the foregoing work from the bankruptcy judge's <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> decision, the documents were presented for his decision according to the facts presented.

Whereas it is stipulated in the first paragraph of Article 89 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> issued by Law No. 71 of 2020 that "the debtor is required, within ten days from the date of approval or rejection of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, to notify the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, the Supervisor <orig>المراقب</orig>, the Bankruptcy Mission <orig>بعثة الإفلاس</orig>, and the concerned regulatory authority – as the case may be – thereof, and to attach the approved or rejected plan, the minutes of the meetings in which the voting took place, and any payments indicating objections raised, attendance at meetings, proof of attendance, and proof of voting. In case of approval of the plan, ratification of the plan shall be requested within the notification."

It is stipulated in Article 82 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> that "the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall, within ten days from the date the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> receives the notification of creditors' approval of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> and its attachments, ratify the proposal after verifying the fulfillment of the following two conditions:
1. That the proposal has obtained the required majority approval.
2. That the proposal meets the criteria of fairness for affected creditors."

It is stipulated in Article 86 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> that "the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> ratified by the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall be enforceable against all creditors covered by it, including creditors who rejected the proposal and those who did not attend the meeting for voting on the proposal. The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall notify, publish, disclose, and register, in accordance with Article (33) of this Law, every decision issued to ratify the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, reject the proposal, suspend ratification, cancel procedures, initiate restructuring procedures, or declare bankruptcy, within ten days from the date of the decision. The bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may suffice with publishing the decision in the bankruptcy register <orig>سجل الإفلاس</orig> and the commercial register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig>."

And by Article (87) of the same Law, it is stipulated that "the debtor is obligated to implement the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> in accordance with what the creditors approved and the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> ratified. He is also obligated, within ten days from the date of implementing the settlement proposal, to notify the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> thereof, and to attach to the notification a statement of the debts that have been settled and the method of settlement, as well as the document proving the settlement. The bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall issue a decision
### Amendment to Preventive Settlement Provisions

upon completion of the implementation of the settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية</orig> and termination of the preventive settlement procedures <orig>إجراءات التسوية الوقائية</orig> within ten days from the date the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> receives the notification. The decision shall have the inherent force of Article (86) of this Law. The bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> may request the opinion of the Supervisor <orig>المراقب</orig>, if appointed, regarding the full implementation of the settlement before issuing the aforementioned decision. He may also request the opinion of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> regarding the full implementation of the settlement, even if the debt is not subject to its supervision, before issuing the aforementioned decision.
<page_end>245</page_end>

Creditors who dispute the validity of the debtor's notification regarding the settlement of their debts may appeal the decision referred to in the preceding paragraph. In the event that the appeal is accepted, the debtor shall be obliged to implement the preventive settlement proposal with the guarantee of the creditor who accepted their appeal, and the preventive settlement proposal shall proceed with the approval of that creditor.

Given the foregoing and proceeding therewith, the applicant company <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> had submitted its current application to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> to commence preventive settlement procedures against the aforementioned bank, in accordance with its submitted application form. After it presented a memorandum containing a brief description of its economic and financial situation and information about its assets, supported by the documents attached to the application, and after the opinion of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> was obtained, as approved by its decision in Report No. (2023/8) dated 11/9/2023, which concluded that, based on the available documents, the applicant company's situation indicates the possibility of continuing its operations and its ability to repay its outstanding debts if the preventive settlement is accepted, the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued a decision on 17/9/2023 to commence preventive settlement procedures. After the decision to commence procedures was issued, the applicant company deposited a copy of the preventive settlement proposal with the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>, and during the period of stay of claims, it requested the necessary attention to persuade the aforementioned creditor to submit its consent to the settlement proposal. It attached to the application the letter from the opposing bank <orig>البنك المتقدم صده</orig> dated 5/2/2024, approving the preventive settlement proposal. A representative of the opposing bank <orig>البنك المتقدم صده</orig> attended the session on 7/3/2024 and confirmed the bank's approval of that proposal and the payment of the settlement amount according to the method referred to in the said letter. The applicant company had no creditors - at the time of

On 8/4/2025, the representative of the applicant company <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> appeared and submitted a letter containing notification of the applicant company's <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> implementation of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>, concluding with a request to issue a decision to terminate the preventive settlement procedures <orig>إجراءات التسوية الوقائية</orig>. Attached to the letter were photocopies of documents proving the implementation of the proposal, supported by the decision of the opposing bank's <orig>البنك المقدم ضده</orig> agent, who was previously the plaintiff, at the session on 16/4/2025, which confirmed the applicant company's <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> implementation of the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig>. Consequently, the applicant company <orig>الشركة الطالبة</orig> (the debtor) has committed to implementing the preventive settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية الوقائية</orig> in accordance with what was approved by the opposing bank <orig>البنك المقدم ضده</orig> (the creditor) and ratified by the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig>. As a result of the foregoing, the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> has been notified of the full implementation of the proposal and has been provided with documents proving the implementation of the settlement. Therefore, the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> has no option but to issue a decision confirming the full implementation of the settlement proposal <orig>مقترح التسوية</orig> and terminating the preventive settlement procedures <orig>إجراءات التسوية الوقائية</orig>, in accordance with the provisions of Article (87) of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>.

(m) of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> requires the bankruptcy judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> to issue a decision terminating the preventive settlement procedures <orig>إجراءات التسوية الوقائية</orig> once they have been implemented and submitted to him by the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig>.

# Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig>
## Announcement issued by the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> entrusting the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> with supervising preventive settlement and insolvency procedures for stakeholders, with the decision recorded in the Bankruptcy Register <orig>سجل الإفلاس</orig> and the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig>, in accordance with the text of Article 33 and the second paragraph of Article 86 of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig>, as this decision will address.
Regarding the fee, since the applicant company (the debtor) has paid the due fee to the clerk, and the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> has concluded by issuing his decision based on the implementation of a proposal and the termination of preventive settlement procedures, it is therefore obligated to pay the fee in accordance with the text of Article 7 of the Executive Regulations of Law No. 71 of 2020 and the source of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> issued by Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig> Resolution No. 81 of 2021.

### It was decided as follows:
Regarding the implementation of the settlement proposal and the termination of preventive settlement procedures, the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall notify the Central Bank <orig>البنك المركزي</orig>, the General Department of Execution <orig>الإدارة العامة للتنفيذ</orig>, the Real Estate Registration Department <orig>إدارة التسجيل العقاري</orig>, Kuwait Municipality <orig>بلدية الكويت</orig>, the applicant company, the bank against which the application was filed, as well as the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> of this decision, with its registration in the Bankruptcy Register <orig>سجل الإفلاس</orig> and the Commercial Register <orig>السجل التجاري</orig> and its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, while obligating the applicant company to pay the fees.

Sunday 13 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1446 AH - 11 / 5 / 2025 AD

### Date of Approval of the Waiver Issued in Application No. 2024/4, Bankruptcy of the Authority

Al-Sayer General Trading and Contracting Company <orig>شركة الساير للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> was represented by its attorney and submitted an application requesting that the court not discharge the debt owed to the company by the applicant, and to acknowledge the applicant's indebtedness to the company. The Industrial Bank of Kuwait <orig>البنك الكويتي الصناعي</orig> was represented and submitted a memorandum which was reviewed, and a portfolio of documents was presented, from which a copy of the bankruptcy application was not requested. The applicant submitted a request that the settlement between it and the applicant must include, after a review between them, and after a pledge and a commercial pledge agreement, and after debt repayment, and after a good overall assessment of the applicant's indebtedness. Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig> was represented by its attorney and requested the rejection of the restructuring plan. Since the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> issued his decision to address the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> to express its opinion, and since the report of the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> dated 2025/1/12 was received, which concluded that there was difficulty in operating the plan submitted by the applicant, and that the financial situation of the debtor company was not good and was approaching a severe liquidity shortage, and that the debtor was unable to manage its affairs, and it was not in the interest of the creditors to entrust the management of the debtor's funds to a trustee. As the application was deliberated in the sessions as recorded in their minutes, Al-Sayer General Trading and Contracting Company <orig>شركة الساير للتجارة العامة والمقاولات</orig> was represented by its attorney and submitted a new debt restructuring plan. The Industrial Bank of Kuwait <orig>البنك الكويتي الصناعي</orig> was represented by its attorney and requested the rejection of the applicant's restructuring plan. The agent of Al-Sayer Facilities Company <orig>شركة تسهيلات الساير</orig> was represented and requested the rejection of the debt restructuring, and therefore requested a postponement to review the new plan. Kuwait Finance House <orig>بيت التمويل الكويتي</orig> was represented and requested the rejection of the debt restructuring.

### Legal Provisions:

Whereas it is stipulated in the text of Articles (1-29-32-33-34-97-102-290) of Bankruptcy Law No. 271/2020 <orig>قانون الإفلاس رقم 271/2020</orig> concerning the provisions of this law, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning specified next to each of them: The debtor's cessation of payment of any claim or compensatory procedure that may be the subject of this debtor, whenever it relates to his funds or assets. The debts related to the estate for the bankruptcy of the authority are the debts of companies listed on the stock exchange and other debts that the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> entrusts the Committee <orig>اللجنة</orig> with supervising. The Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> shall, within ten days from the date of its notification of the application - after which the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall set a shorter or longer period for submitting all debts related to the estate's liabilities and submitting a report to the Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> concerning it, which shall include the following matters: 1- The possibility of preventive settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig> or restructuring, or the lack thereof. 2- Whether precautionary measures <orig>تدابير تحفظية</orig> should be taken urgently or not, and this is permissible if the debtor is able to manage his affairs and funds himself. 3- Whether the debtor has managed his affairs and funds well in managing the debtor's funds and liabilities. 4- The Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> shall decide on the application within ten days from the date of the expiry of the period specified for him, by issuing a decision to open preventive settlement <orig>التسوية الوقائية</orig> or restructuring procedures... And the Bankruptcy Judge <orig

Therefore, we have decided the following:
To commence restructuring procedures regarding the request submitted by: 1- A.M. Information and Equipment Company (Sole Proprietorship) <orig>شركة إيه إم للمعلومات والمعدات (شركة الشخص الواحد)</orig>, and 2- Anwar Badr Hassan Mohammed <orig>أنور بدر حسن محمد</orig>, with the suspension of all judicial claims and enforcement procedures taken against them until the date of issuance of a decision regarding the restructuring plan. The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> is tasked with seeking the opinion of one of the persons nominated to them by the Capital Markets Authority <orig>هيئة سوق المال</orig> or registered with it in the register of auditors regarding assuming the task of the trustee, provided that this is communicated promptly. The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall notify the applicants, creditors, and the Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig> of this decision in accordance with Article 55 of Bankruptcy Law No. 71 of 2020 <orig>قانون الإفلاس رقم 2020/71</orig> and publish it in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, while tasking the debtor with preparing a restructuring proposal and forming a creditors' committee within the legally prescribed period.

Bankruptcy Committee <orig>لجنة الإفلاس</orig>

Decision No. (23) of 2024 (Bankruptcy)

The facts are summarized in the two decisions of the Bankruptcy Judge <orig>قاضي الإفلاس</orig> in the present application, issued on 2025/2/17 and 2025/4/10, to open the door for electronic claims for a period of one month starting from the date of publication of the first decision, and to extend the period for submitting electronic claims for an additional month starting from the date of expiry of the previous decision, to which both are referred to avoid repetition.
Whereas the Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> requested an extension of the deadline for submitting claims and debts for an additional month starting from the date of expiry of the last decision, based on the desire of some creditors who were unable to submit their applications during the two previous periods, it was therefore decided to extend the period for submitting electronic claims for an additional month starting from the date of expiry of the previous decision issued on 2025/4/10.

Therefore, we have decided the following:

1- Extend the period for submitting electronic claims for an additional month starting from the date of expiry of the previous decision issued on 2025/4/10.

2- The Bankruptcy Department <orig>إدارة الإفلاس</orig> shall provide the Trustee <orig>الأمين</orig> with a certified true copy of this decision, publish and announce it in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, and legally notify the concerned parties.

After reviewing the papers and the letter from the Public Investment Authority <orig>الهيئة العامة للاستثمار</orig> No. MAS 550/21/10 dated 27/4/2025, approval is requested for interim distributions in favor of the State's debt to satisfy its aforementioned debt, specific to the provisions of Law No. (41/1993), in light of the final list of debts for the bankrupt / Mr. Hussein Makki Al-Jumaa <orig>حسين مكي الجمعة</orig>, and in accordance with the provisions of the Bankruptcy Law and its executive regulations.

And whereas Articles (179 - 195) of the Bankruptcy Law have outlined the liquidation and distribution procedures.

Head of Bankruptcy Administration <orig>رئيس إدارة الإفلاس</orig>

- And on Ministerial Resolutions numbers (62), (67), (75), (79),
(96), and (97) for the year 2020.
- And Consumer Protection Agency <orig>جهاز حماية المستهلك</orig> Resolution No. (14) of 2021 regarding the issuance of the Executive Regulations for Law No. 72 of 2020 concerning Competition Protection <orig>حماية المنافسة</orig>, amended by Resolution No. 25 of 2022.
- And on what was presented by the Undersecretary of the Ministry.
- And based on what the public interest requires.
- And pursuant to the powers vested in us.
It was decided

## Article (1)

A central committee, known as the "Central Committee for Price Study, Inflation Monitoring, and Supply Chains," shall be formed within the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>, chaired by the Undersecretary of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وكيل وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>. The committee shall include as members (at a rank not less than a department director or its equivalent) representatives from the following entities:

1.  A representative from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry <orig>وزارة التجارة والصناعة</orig>.
2.  A representative from the Ministry of Social Affairs and Family and Childhood Affairs <orig>وزارة الشؤون الاجتماعية وشؤون الأسرة والطفولة</orig>.
3.  A representative from Kuwait University <orig>جامعة الكويت</orig>.
4.  A representative from the Union of Cooperative Societies <orig>اتحاد الجمعيات التعاونية</orig>.
5.  A representative from the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research <orig>معهد الكويت للأبحاث العلمية</orig>.
6.  A representative from the Public Authority for Food and Nutrition <orig>الهيئة العامة للغذاء والتغذية</orig>.
7.  A representative from the General Administration of Customs <orig>الإدارة العامة للجمارك</orig>.
8.  A representative from the General Fire Force <orig>قوة الإطفاء العام</orig>.
9.  A representative from the Kuwait Supply Company <orig>الشركة الكويتية للتموين</orig>.
10. A representative from the Competition Protection Agency <orig>جهاز حماية المنافسة</orig>.
11. A representative from the Consumer Protection Society <orig>جمعية حماية المستهلك</orig>.
12. A representative from the Central Statistical Bureau <orig>الإدارة المركزية للإحصاء</orig>.
13. A representative from the Kuwaiti Union of Poultry Producers <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي لمنتجي الدواجن</orig>.
14. A representative from the Union of Distributors of Consumer Goods for Wholesale and Retail Trade <orig>اتحاد موزعي المواد الاستهلاكية لتجارة الجملة والتجزئة</orig>.
15. A representative from the Kuwaiti Union of Food Traders and Manufacturers <orig>الاتحاد الكويتي لتجار ومصنعي المواد الغذائية</orig>.

The committee may, when necessary, seek assistance from experts and specialists, provided that they do not have the right to vote.

## Article (2)

### Competencies of the Central Committee

The Central Committee shall be responsible for the following tasks:

1.  Monitoring and determining prices in various markets across the country, and establishing controls and mechanisms to ensure their stability.
2.  Studying local inflation rates and proposing appropriate recommendations to address them and mitigate their effects.
3.  Monitoring supply chains to ensure their robustness and efficiency, and submitting proposals that contribute to ensuring the regular flow of goods and services.

-4- Enhancing market competitiveness by proposing policies that incentivize manufacturers and importers to provide goods in appropriate quantities and at suitable prices.
-5- Combating commercial dumping and protecting national products, based on relevant decisions, especially Decision No. (2024/222) regarding construction materials.
-6- Reviewing reports issued by sub-committees and making appropriate decisions regarding them, while submitting periodic reports to the Minister <orig>الوزير</orig> that include the most important developments and recommendations.

### Article (3)
The Central Committee <orig>اللجنة المركزية</orig> may, by a decision issued by it, establish specialized sub-committees as it deems appropriate. These committees may include, but are not limited to, the following:

1.  Price Monitoring Committee <orig>لجنة متابعة الأسعار</orig>:
    a- The committee is responsible for analyzing and monitoring price movements in the markets, and preparing periodic reports on developments and the need for regulatory intervention when necessary.
    b- The committee works to approve price adjustments and review the introduction of new products, while providing appropriate recommendations to ensure market balance.
    c- The committee monitors the impact of price changes to ensure their stability and protect consumers from unjustified fluctuations, taking into account economic and commercial factors.
    d- The committee is responsible for approving price increases for goods. No increase in any current market price is permitted except after a decision is issued by this committee, and any increase made without its approval is considered a violation of the law.

2.  Inflation Rate Monitoring Committee <orig>لجنة متابعة نسب التضخم</orig>:
    a- It specializes in studying local and international inflation factors and analyzing their impact on local markets.
    b- Evaluating economic factors affecting inflation rates and providing recommendations to mitigate their negative effects.
    c- Monitoring global price developments and their impact on import costs and their repercussions on the local market.

3.  Market and Supply Chain Regulation Committee <orig>لجنة تنظيم الأسواق وسلاسل الإمداد</orig>:
    a- Establishing controls and procedures that regulate supply and demand operations in the markets to prevent bottlenecks and achieve balance.
